name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Mr Costas Chrysogonos, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs, on monitoring the implementation of EU law in 2015 (2017/2011 (INI)) (A8-0265/ 2017)

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος
text: Rapporteur. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking all the members of the European Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs who have contributed to the completion of my report on the implementation of EU law in 2015. Regular and consistent monitoring of the application of European law is crucial for the proper functioning of the European Union institutions and for the improvement of its universally acknowledged weaknesses. The relevant report of the European Commission focuses on the formal application of European legislation by the Member States. On the other hand, however, I fear that it underestimates the real risks of violating fundamental European principles and values, which have become entrenched in the practices of the institutions and of the Union itself. These risks need to be identified if we are to tackle the challenges of the future effectively. The key areas in which the Commission report notes that most infringement proceedings against Member States occurred due to late transposition of European rules in their domestic legal order in 2015 are workers' mobility, transport, energy and the environment. Although in 2015, for the first time since 2011, the number of new complaints of breaches of European law is declining, there are concerns that a significant number of new complaints concern sensitive areas, such as employment, social affairs, social inclusion, entrepreneurship and justice. However, the responsibility of the Member States for the application of European law does not in any way relieve the institutions of the Union itself of their duty to respect and act on EU law. The institutions of the European Union, even when acting as members of a group of international creditors, are bound by the Treaties of the Union and the Charter of Fundamental Rights. The practice of Union institutions to sign memoranda of understanding with creditors with Member States under which they undertake to implement burdensome austerity measures, without such agreements being subject to European law, is reprehensible. Onerous measures, such as continuous cuts in salaries and pensions, continuous increases in taxes and levies resulting from these agreements, and in some cases violating constitutional rights, lack basic safeguards. These flaws are also provided by EU law, as well as the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union incorporated into primary law. It is also pointed out that, due to the imposition of substantial cuts in the administration, justice, health and social welfare through such measures, the protection of fundamental rights and principles, such as the right to health, the right to work, the protection of dignity human beings and the welfare state in general is being undermined. Such practices are therefore not in line with the legal culture of the Union. At the same time, the lack of implementation of the rules governing asylum and immigration from third countries to the Union must be emphasized. This is particularly true of the refugee relocation mechanism, as some Member States do not comply with this agreement. In this way, however, the fundamental principle of European solidarity and cooperation is undermined and the prestige of the European Union is damaged. In conclusion, the application of EU law must be comprehensive and not selective if the Union is to convince its citizens that it respects its principles and thus improve the long-term prospects of its own sustainability.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, in Europe the strength of the law has replaced the law of the strong. Our Union is not a state, but it is a community of law. Proper application of the law ensures that individuals and companies can enjoy their rights, that they obtain legal certainty in their daily lives and obtain rapid and effective redress if rights are violated. Together with the Council, the European Parliament can adopt the best law in the world, but unless it is properly applied it will not change anything, so on behalf of First Vice-President Frans Timmermans, I welcome the fact that this House so strongly shares the Commission’s view that making sure that European Union law is properly implemented, and effectively complied with, has to be permanently among our top priorities. For that reason, this Chamber’s continuous work on our annual reports is particularly important. There have been a number of significant developments since 2015. I think these developments respond to a great number of the issues have raised. In particular, Members call for strengthened enforcement and monitoring of the implementation of the European Union legislation in key policy areas. Since 2016, the Commission’s new enforcement policy does exactly that. We have put forward a more strategic, effective and proportionate approach to our infringement policy to allow us to deliver on our policy priorities. Importantly, we will now launch infringement procedures without first relying on the EU pilot mechanism, unless recource to this mechanism is seen as useful in a particular case. On transparency, we have taken concrete measures to provide more information about infringement decisions. In 2014 we set up a centralised platform for proactively disseminating information on infringements on our Europa website in all Union languages, and we are making an ongoing effort to improve the accessibility and user—friendliness of this website even more.  We will continue to provide Parliament and the public at large with information on the follow—up given to complaints and Parliamentary petitions in our annual reports. We must do this, of course, while respecting confidentiality with regard to the Member States in infringement procedures as recognised by the Court of Justice.  In recent years this House has dedicated considerable energy to better regulation and the Commission very much welcomes that. Our shared aim, reflected in the Institutional Agreement on Better Law—making, is to ensure legislation is prepared in an open, transparent way using the best evidence available and valuable stakeholder input. We also focus on ways to support Member States in their implementation of European rules and are pleased to see that Parliament supports these efforts. We also pay particular attention to the national authorities who have key tasks under EU law, such as national competent authorities, national data protection supervisory authorities and national rail, energy and telecoms regulators. We will continue to work in partnership with them through the range of networks we have in place. As you will know, we reported on the latest developments on better regulation in a communication adopted this Thursday alongside the Commission Work Programme for 2018.  I also support your call for a more active role for national parliaments in the dialogue on the European Union’s legislative proposals. The Commission has invested heavily in the political dialogue with national parliaments, as well as the formal consultation mechanisms set out in the Treaty. Over the last three years, Members of the Commission have visited national parliaments more than 650 times. They also participated in more than 300 interactive citizens’ dialogues in more than 80 cities and towns across 27 Member States. Finally, we will continue to strengthen our cooperation with the European Network of Ombudsmen, which the European Ombudsman coordinates and which promotes good administration in the application of EU law at national level.  There are nevertheless two issues which we have also discussed in the past and where we do not fully agree.  First, your call for an increased role for Parliament in monitoring the implementation of EU law. Without prejudice to the essential democratic control by Parliament, it is the Commission which oversees the application of European Union law, under the control of the Court of Justice of the European Union.  The infringement procedure has a specific bilateral nature recognised in the Treaty. It is conducted solely between the Commission and the Member State concerned. There are thus legal limits as regards the role of Parliament in this process.  Second, you call again for a legislative proposal on administrative procedures under Article 298 of the Treaty. I would like to stress two points here. Firstly, the Commission has already created a strong framework to protect complainants. Our Code of Good Administrative Behaviour and the Communication on relations with the complainant offer a number of guarantees that safeguard complainants’ rights throughout the entire procedure. Secondly, as the EU administers a range of diverse, often highly—specialised activities, we need sector—specific rules. Citizens and businesses concerned by such specialised activities are guaranteed specific administrative rights which are guaranteed by the Court of Justice of the European Union.  Against this background, the Commission still remains to be convinced of the added value of a legal instrument that would codify administrative law. The effective application of European Union law is essential to deliver the benefits of European policies to citizens, businesses and public administrations. The Commission welcomes the fact that it has such a strong partner as the Parliament in ensuring that the laws you pass are implemented properly so that they really deliver positive benefits on the ground.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski
text: author of the draft opinion of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs. - Mr Chairman! Many thanks to Mr Christogonos for his opinion. Our opinion is an auxiliary opinion and covers the entire process of law application in a broader aspect. First of all, we want to draw attention to the fact that well-applied law requires that already at the stage of drafting legal acts - this is primarily an appeal to the European Commission - the law should be economical, non-bureaucratic, coherent and understandable for citizens. The better the projects in the initial phase, the better the application of the law will be. The same remark applies to the transposition of directives into national law: they should not be burdened with additional content that complicates the law and creates bureaucratic barriers. The AFCO commission places emphasis on transparency of the entire process as a condition for public scrutiny and for ensuring the right of citizens to be informed about the law-making process. We attach great importance to strengthening the role of national parliaments as partners of European institutions. We are considering loosening the rules so that national parliaments, in the first phase of early warning and the application of the principle of subsidiarity, have more possibilities than before. This will be for the good application of the law. These are the main issues raised by the AFCO Committee.

name: Cecilia Wikström
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Petitions. – Mr President, the Committee on Petitions, for which I am chair, is, at its very best, a tool that bridges the gap between the EU institutions and the citizens. The Treaties guarantee all citizens the right to petition my Committee on the difficulties and problems that they face in their everyday life. In 2015, we received 1 431 petitions. Some of them refer to clear violation of EU law. The most common concerns remain within the areas of the environment, justice, fundamental rights and the internal market.  Altogether, this shows us at least three different things. Firstly, that we have a long way to go before EU legislation is applied equally all over the European Union, in every Member State. Secondly, it shows us the importance of petitions as a monitoring tool at grassroots level: the petitioners raise our awareness not only of violations of EU law, but also of deficiencies and loopholes that exist in the legislation. Thirdly, it shows that the EU is crucial in securing the wellbeing of its citizens where the nation state fails or ignores its responsibilities. We must remember that the application and the implementation of EU law is ultimately the responsibility of the Member States. As the number of infringement procedures initiated by the Commission was still at a high level in 2015, I would strongly urge the Member States to look into this and into their performance when it comes to implementation of EU law. We must ensure that the rights and the opportunities offered by EU legislation are maximised to benefit all the citizens of the Union, irrespective of which Member State they happen to live in.

name: Daniel Buda
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, first of all, I would like to express my appreciation for the work of my colleagues and the rapporteur. Uniform and timely transposition of Union-wide legislation is absolutely necessary, so that citizens of all Member States enjoy the benefits of European Union policy at the same time. The Commission's report revealed that there are still problems with the application of European law in most Member States. Late or incorrect transposition of these rules adversely affects legal certainty and prevents citizens from effectively and equally benefiting from the rights recognized at European level. I believe that, in this context, the Commission needs to identify areas where there are difficulties in transposing legislation, in order to identify the solutions that need to be put in place and not just to provide an overview. I would also like to emphasize the role of EU Pilot procedures, which aim at closer cooperation between the Commission and the Member States, to remedy infringements of European Union legislation from the outset, without resorting to formal infringement proceedings. . However, every European state must refrain from over-regulation at national level, as this automatically leads to administrative complications, which have a negative impact on citizens' lives. Moreover, cumbersome, incoherent and often changed national legislation jeopardizes the effectiveness of European Union policies in various areas, such as cohesion policy and the common agricultural policy. This is particularly the case in the field of regulation of procedures for the absorption of European funds, where Member States add additional conditions beyond European regulations and directives. I therefore consider it necessary for the Commission to intervene in order to limit such over-regulation.Ensuring the timely and correct application of Union law in the Member States remains a considerable and ongoing challenge.We must remember, however, that this contributes significantly to investment growth, economic growth, but also to the increase in the number of jobs.That is why my political group and I personally believe that it is necessary to reject by vote all amendments that fight the legitimacy of European policies.

name: Sylvia-Yvonne Kaufmann
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Mister President! Two figures are particularly interesting: On the one hand, it should be noted that in 2015, for the first time since 2011, the number of new complaints from citizens, companies or organizations about potential violations of EU law fell. That is encouraging, although around 3,500 complaints a year are still quite a lot. And then the second number: in the same year - 2015 - the Commission launched 742 new infringement procedures against Member States. The delayed or incorrect implementation of European laws undoubtedly has negative effects on general legal certainty and also on the competitive conditions in the internal market. And if you then have to say that in 2015, of all things, the most complaints about violations of EU law were received again in the employment sector, then you don't need to be surprised why citizens perceive that their social and Do not improve workers' rights. We see it again and again that when there are problems, loud references are made to “those in Brussels”. Oh, it's so easy and so incredibly popular to make Brussels a scapegoat. But it cannot go on like this. It is high time that, when the European Union and its problems are discussed, the horses and riders are specifically named, that is, it is clearly stated who is responsible for what and who bears political responsibility. The Commission is responsible for legislative proposals and, as guardian of the Treaties, ensures compliance with European law, and the Member States are responsible for implementing European laws once they have been adopted and applying them properly. They must not evade this responsibility. They must finally carry out their duties so that we can all take advantage of European legislation can perceive.Finally, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Chrysogonos, for his excellent work and good cooperation.

name: Ангел Джамбазки
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr President, I congratulate my colleague, Chrysogonos, on his work on the report. Adapting Member States' legislation to the normal Union legal system is a complex and time-consuming process. Very often it causes a number of difficulties that cannot always be solved in a timely manner. On the other hand, delays in the transposition of Union law prevent individuals and businesses from benefiting from European rules, confusing the rules applied and having a negative impact on the functioning of the Union's internal market. I welcome the rapporteur's view that the responsibility for the correct application of Union law lies not only with the Member States but also with the Union institutions, which must respect the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. I support the rapporteur's view that the involvement of national parliaments in the dialogue on the content of legislative annexes will promote more effective application of European Union law. However, I do not agree with his arguments on the migration and asylum procedure. Finally, I would like to emphasize that the Commission is the guardian of the Treaties, but that does not entitle it to interfere in the internal affairs of the democratically elected governments of the Member States.

name: Jean-Marie Cavada
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, this report is really very useful and I would first like to thank our colleague, Mr Chrysogonos, for all the nuances he has made and the effort he has made to ensure that it is a fundamental report , because it shows that the responsibility of States is increasingly taken into account and that this matter is progressing so that we have consistency in the European Union. Obviously, this report also reflects the fact that the efforts that the Member States have made, will make and, in any case, must make are absolutely fundamental for the democratic relationship between our institutions and the voters, the citizens of the whole. of the Union. I will issue a restriction first before giving my full support. I do not share all the ideas that are in this report, and in particular, dear colleagues, when the rapporteur establishes a causal link between the restrictive financial measures imposed by the Union on certain Member States and the incorrect application of EU law. 'Union, or when it is deplored that the annual reviews by the Commission, the European Central Bank or the Council of economic adjustment programs intended for members of the euro area are not carried out in a - I would say - democratic. In reality, in substance, I will support this report, which I will obviously vote for. On a number of essential points, he says things really very well: on respect for fundamental rights which seem to me to be the cornerstone, on the migration crisis, on the responsibility of the Member States which do not respect the quotas of reception of the refugees, which is a heavy stain on our behavior, and then on environmental law violations. On these points, I believe that our rapporteur has shed light, in a way that everyone can understand, how we must move forward in the transposition of European law in the Member States and explain it to voters.

name: Jiří Maštálka
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, I read with great interest Mr Chrysogonos's report on the application of the law in the European Union in 2015. I must say that I was unpleasantly surprised by the number of 3,450 complaints to the Commission about possible infringements in the European Union. Perhaps this suggests that the legislation being adopted is complex and incomprehensible. At a time of growing Euroscepticism, we should be discussing, in particular, which legislation is redundant and burdensome and which, on the contrary, is beneficial to citizens at European level. This means what common EU legislation can improve the quality of life and ensure economic development. For example, European cooperation in tackling gender pay inequality, which is as high as 16% in the European Union, can only be beneficial. Such inequality is, of course, unjustifiable. I also believe that we should focus more on applying the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. I also consider greater involvement of national parliaments to be necessary. National parliaments must be able to express their views at an early stage in the legislative process, and the so-called early warning system must be revised to ensure better application of the Yellow Card procedure. We do not want more unnecessary regulation and more administrative burden. When drafting legislation, we must pay more attention to the social partners, civil society, and consumer protection organizations. The aim is a more transparent and open legislative process, simple, clear and comprehensible legislation that will reduce bureaucracy.

name: Heidi Hautala
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, the principle of the rule of law, as recalled in Article 2 of the Treaty of the European Union, is the foundation of the Union. The principle of legality, as a corollary to the rule of law, requires that activities of the Union’s administration are carried out in full accordance with the law. With the development of the competencies of the European Union, citizens are increasingly confronted with the Union’s institutions and procedures in their daily lives. Despite this increase, the procedures remain opaque, rules unclear and the people do not know what their rights are or if there is a remedy. In other words, alongside the expansion of administrative procedures, the EU has failed to ensure that the procedural rights that are affected will be adequately protected. Yet, in a Union under the rule of law, it is necessary that procedural rights and obligations be clearly defined and complied with. It remains the case that the Union lacks a coherent and comprehensive set of codified rules of administrative law. Not only does this enable poor, non-transparent and inconsistent administration, it makes it difficult for citizens to understand their administrative rights under Union law. The right to good administration requires that administrative acts should be taken by the Union’s administration pursuant to clear and accessible administrative procedures which guarantee impartiality, fairness and timeliness. In its resolution of 15 January 2013, the European Parliament called for the adoption of a regulation on a European law of administrative procedure, to legally guarantee the right to good administration, by means of an open, efficient and independent European administration. However, despite the fact that the motion for a resolution was adopted in plenary by an overwhelming majority, Parliament’s request has not been followed up by a Commission proposal. Last year, I asked my colleagues in the Committee on Legal Affairs to draft the regulation together with me if the Commission would not do it, and we did it. The text was endorsed by the Committee in June last year and the European Parliament in its plenary adopted it. It called for the Commission to come forward with a comprehensive legislative proposal. Mr President, the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon would give us the full obligation to implement the right to good administration and I am extremely disappointed to hear once again from the Commission, as we heard, that the Commission still remains to be convinced about the need for a unified law on administrative procedure.

name: Jane Collins
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, all Member States have very distinct legal cultures. The legal system of the UK is very different to the rest of continental Europe. A blanket policy cannot work in this Union. It saddens me to see that this report is calling on the Commission to urge Member States to ensure the strict enforcement of EU rules on the free movement of persons. The EU cannot force an EU migration policy on countries which are already dealing with very difficult internal problems, such as housing and financial commitments. I also note with concern that the emphasis of this report is on bringing sovereign nation states ‘back into line’. The report’s references to ensuring the EU institutions themselves comply with EU law could almost be obligatory. This is not a periphery matter. This report, like the EU institutions themselves, has failed to consider who guards the guards.

name: Gilles Lebreton
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, the Chrysogonos report takes stock of the application by European States of Union law in 2015. It responds to the usual canons of the wooden tongue, singing the praises of the Brussels Commission and welcoming the irresistible march of the Union towards the radiant future of a federal Europe. Nothing is missing, not even allegiance to the lobbies, modestly renamed "civil society organizations", or tribute to the Committee of the Regions, whose work of undermining is destroying Spain. A great achievement indeed! But the reality is stubborn. Suddenly the relationship becomes cloudy! In paragraph 31, he expressed concern about the austerity imposed by the Union on Greece. It is true that the author of the report is Greek and that it is difficult to ignore the devastation of which his country is the victim. He even ended up confessing, in paragraph 33, his concern at the refusal of certain Eastern European States to apply the relocations of migrants ordered by the Commission. This is all pathetic! Instead of pledging allegiance to the Commission, the author of the report would have done better to attack Schengen, whose bankruptcy is responsible for the migratory flooding that his country, Greece is experiencing.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: - Officer! I have a question for you, please answer. How they decide when to initiate proceedings for actual or alleged breaches of EU standards and when not. As their report shows, they never hesitate to take action, for example, against my country, Hungary, when we do not comply with the European Union's - often arbitrary - migration standards because we want to protect our country. However, they never seem to initiate proceedings when there are huge lobbies on the other side of the banking world. I am thinking here primarily of foreign currency credit matters. In my country, Hungary, many tens of thousands of people are now at risk of execution, of losing their homes. If one looks at EU consumer protection standards, these are just a few of them. You do not even have to be a lawyer to see that these foreign currency banking transactions have sharply run counter to all EU consumer protection standards, just as these people are now being enforced while the European Court of Justice is still pending in these cases. . Please inform the Hungarian public about the position of the European Union on this issue. Thanks!

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE).
text: - Mr President, the European Union is a community of law, and I am glad that we can discuss this report prepared by Mr Chrysogonos and thank him for his work on it. I would like to say that, as Mr Maštálka also said, there are examples of legislation where the European Commission could really propose a change to them, for example a pointless directive on alternating winter and summer time is a hot candidate for change, because not only has it been harmful but that does nothing good. Secondly, I cannot agree with the proposal of the Confederal Group of the European United Left / Nordic Green Left to amend, which says that the application of European Union law is contrary to the well-being of the vast majority of Europe's population. Firstly, this is not true in fact, because European Union law contributes to European integration and it contributes to the well-being of the vast majority of Europe's population. Secondly, I do not agree that law, including European law, should be used as an instrument of class struggle. I enjoyed it a lot in my youth when I was studying at the Communist Law School.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, rapporteur, ladies and gentlemen, as the Social Democratic Rapporteur on the opinion of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, I am concerned about the timely and correct implementation of Community law in national law. This continues to be a major challenge due to the large number of infringement proceedings, which, of course, has a negative impact on the completion of the internal single market. Indeed, the main responsibility for the correct implementation and application of Union law lies with the Member States. However, the institutions of the European Union, namely the Commission, must ensure that the tools made available to the Member States, such as textbooks, expert groups, special online platforms, are sufficient and truly address the problems of transposition. In addition, I am disappointed that, when it comes to transposing legislation, the three areas where Member States have been most affected by infringement proceedings have been the transport sector, energy and the environment. However, we must not forget that these sectors are characterized by a certain specificity. In this regard, I invited the Commission to explain the reasons for this situation. I believe that, in order to meet the deadlines for transposition, the Commission should also set realistic implementation deadlines, right from the pre-legislative phase, as administrative capacity and infrastructure needs differ from one Member State to another. Therefore, obviously, efforts to adjust national legislation could also require countries to double their actions or measures, especially since, in certain situations and in the case of certain Member States, the Commission comes with additional conditions, which affect the capacity of those countries. countries to implement European legislation or benefit from the use of funds and financing and this directly affects investment and jobs and, implicitly, national and European economies.One positive aspect, however, is that this report also reflects a position that encourages better law-making at the EU level, and this is the procedure we need to focus on in the future.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR).
text: - Mister President! The Commission is the guardian of the Treaties. So far, so good, or more precisely one would have to say: So far, so bad. Because if I take two large and important areas, for example migration and the euro zone, then I do not see that the Commission is fulfilling its mandate to actually enforce compliance with these treaties. We have an agreement from Dublin and there is clear regulation of how to behave in the area of ​​migration. It is violated permanently. That is one of the main reasons why we in the EU are in such a big crisis. If I take the Maastricht Treaty, then I have to say: It is absurd that it is violated dozen of times - well over a hundred times - without sanctions. The EU is unlikely to accept that. Especially not that we have a European institution - with the European Central Bank - which in principle does what it wants. It is exceeding its mandate, it is taking action that is in no way sustainable and it will be the burden of the EU citizens, the taxpayers, to do so. I ask the Commission to remedy this.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank and acknowledge the work of our colleague Chrysogonos, rapporteur for this report.Article 42 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights says that every natural or legal person has the right to access the documentation of the European Union.From the Petitions Committee, we reiterate that we must make this right effective.We need to know the details of the investigation procedures - I am not talking about infringement procedures, but investigation procedures - opened by the European Commission in relation to petitions.But, even more so, we need to have access to the files of those procedures when it comes to petitions that are open and we have to clarify about them.If not, we are undermining the credibility of these European institutions, which is already badly damaged and of which we are all aware.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, petitions are an indispensable tool for informing the European institutions about the serious shortcomings in the application of Union law. It is therefore essential to listen to the voice of citizens and take concrete action to try to find solutions. Only in this way can we truly contribute to solving the problems caused by the misapplication of EU law and avoid situations where social justice, fundamental rights and environmental protection are denied. I would like to give examples, in particular relating to the serious shortcomings in the application and implementation of environmental and air quality legislation. I am thinking, for example, of my country, of Italy, against which infringement procedures have been in place for years now concerning the exceeding of atmospheric pollutants that cause, every year, Italy's sad record of 86,000 premature deaths. cause of air pollution. This is obviously an unacceptable problem, which must be managed at Member State level, but for which the European Commission also has great responsibility. I think of the dieselgate scandal, I think of what happened in 2015, when the European Commission, however, was careful not to fully, promptly and effectively exercise its control powers to prevent the placing on the market of diesel cars. non-compliant in terms of homologation. Obviously, the lobbying interests of car manufacturers have been listened to and not the health of citizens. I also want to recall the delays accumulated in other infringement procedures, in other areas of EU law. I am thinking, for example, of the abuse of fixed-term contracts in the public sector, which condemns thousands and millions of citizens to insecurity and, finally, the failure to relocate migrants, a scandal for this Europe. I close by recalling the many petitions on the subject of well-being animal.It is unacceptable that the Union's strategy is still firm and cannot be concretely applied.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE).
text: - Mr President, effectively, the effective application of European Union law has to be a priority for all the institutions, because it increases the feeling of belonging and trust of European citizens towards their institutions. It is really very important at this time that this confidence is increased; in addition, it ensures that there are no inequalities and greatly favors legal certainty. The Commission is undoubtedly responsible for applying and enforcing European legislation. And that is why I want to encourage the Commission to play an active role in that mission and make it a political priority for it. Undoubtedly, the supervision of compliance with this legislation with the structured dialogue before opening an infringement procedure favors that there are no such procedures and that it can be applied in a satisfactory way. The Member States also have a very high responsibility. For this, it is necessary for the transposition to be carried out and for the transposition to be carried out within realistic deadlines, which make it possible to actually enforce and apply that Union Law. In the Committee on Petitions - its president said - we have been able to see many petitions regarding human rights, justice, the internal market and, above all, the environment and accessibility. Issues that concern citizens and that effectively have to do with the difficulty in applying this European legislation. It is an opportunity to make this sense of belonging of European citizenship to these European values ​​a reality. I share in general lines the report of the rapporteur, except on one issue: criticizing legitimate European decisions - some colleagues have said it here - and, taking advantage of the fact that Pisuerga passes through Valladolid, making criticisms of an ideological bias in a report that it aims to be assessing the application of European legislation does not make much sense. I think what we have to do with this The report is to see how we can improve the implementation of this legislation and strengthen, above all, the credibility of the European institutions.Using the report for ideological issues produces just the opposite effect.I think it is time to adjust to the debate, to be serious and to generate those trusts.

name: Sergio Gaetano Cofferati (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, what Mr Chrysogonos and his collaborators did is an excellent job, which allows us to fully address the problem we are discussing. Now it is very important to legislate well, always. It is equally important, however, to check that the laws are applied promptly and correctly: promptly because, in the elements detected continuously over the last few years, the difference between the moment of approval of the standard and its implementation, even when this occurs, is in my opinion frankly excessive, especially for some issues. Then we saw how for other subjects, in truth, the application is erratic or even non-existent. It is undoubtedly a good thing that the number of offenses detected or delays detected has dropped over the last few years. It is not reassuring, however, that what remains is mainly linked to the legislative conditions affecting work and the rights of people who work. In this, a great deal of determination is needed on the part of the Commission: it cannot be accepted that, for example, in a very delicate matter such as immigration there is a avoidance of the obligations previously discussed and agreed upon. Just as the same thing is not acceptable with regard to one of the most delicate issues that have emerged over the last few months, that of the tax authorities. Taxation has become an instrument of competition between EU countries. Compliance with the rules, even if this is a matter that still belongs to the competence of the Member States, is essential. It is therefore very important that this be noted, that the appropriate measures are implemented. In the same way, I believe, finally, that it is very useful for the national parliaments to address the issues we discussed this morning with the same conviction and with the same determination.

name: Anders Primdahl Vistisen (ECR).
text: - Sir. Chairman! It is symptomatic of today's debate, which is about how we, as Parliament and the Commission, must ensure compliance with EU law, that we avoid all the key issues. The key problems are that there is a clear double standard in the EU in relation to which infringements the Commission takes seriously and which infringements are not liked to be addressed. We can just look at the whole of the euro area, how year after year, year after year, countries such as France and Germany have violated the rules that they themselves have implemented for the euro area, without the Commission taking action on a treaty basis. As my colleague mentioned earlier, the Dublin Convention and Germany's breach of it, in the midst of the biggest refugee crisis in Europe's recent history, is also an example of failure. So now let's do away with the double standards. If the EU is to be a society based on equal rules for all, then the Commission must also take a stand against the big countries, instead of just going after the small fish in the small areas.

name: Νικόλαος Χουντής (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, happy birthday. Commissioner, for my country, Greece, the application of European Union law in 2015 is synonymous with the overthrow of democracy and popular sovereignty. In 2015, the Greek people democratically decided to change the neoliberal economic policies pursued by the Greek governments and the troika in previous years. The Greek people, with 62% in the referendum, voted against the continuation of the memoranda imposed by the troika. The European Union institutions responded to this sovereign decision with an economic coup. Armed with the closure of banks, they blackmailed Greece into signing for the third time the sale of the country, the cuts in income and pensions, and the deregulation of the labor market. In other words, they have again imposed memoranda that, among other things, violate the Charter of Fundamental Rights by common confession and have led to poverty and unemployment. Now the guardians of the Treaties and the governments implementing the memoranda are denouncing each other for illegality but at the same time cooperating to enforce the policy of austerity. Commissioner, the Greek people have condemned these policies, they consider the European institutions and governments to be co-responsible for the disasters they have caused and they will give them the appropriate response.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D).
text: - Mr Chairman! The European Commission, as the guardian of the Treaties, should be the guarantor of the application of Community law, for that to happen in practice, it is necessary to further improve the transposition of the law in the Member States and to ensure that it is duly respected. In 2015, the Commission received 3,450 complaints about alleged breaches of EU law. The Member States affected by most of the complaints were Italy, Spain and Germany. The large number of ongoing infringement procedures shows that the correct application of EU law remains a major challenge. At the end of 2015, 1,368 cases of non-compliance with the obligations of Member States were opened, which is a slight increase compared to the previous year, but this is still a smaller number of cases than in 2011, which is a kind of optimistic signal. Correct transposition and implementation of EU law into national legislation in a timely manner and a transparent national legislative framework ensuring full respect for the fundamental values ​​and rights enshrined in the Treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union should be a priority for the Member States to avoid breaches of Community law, as in effect, it violates the due protection of citizens. Finally, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on a well-prepared document.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: - The rule of law depends primarily on the control of power, and the rule of law in the European Union depends on the control of the European Union authorities. If any authority comes to the conclusion that the allegations that it does not follow the principles it relies on are absurd and inadmissible, it may end up like the authority which placed its opponents in psychiatric hospitals. Of course, for now, critics of the European Union authorities are treated only as opponents of Europe, but it is still outrageous. I hope one day we will turn back from this path. Unfortunately, we very often see that specific violations of the law in the Member States, on which we would only expect a verbal position, are ignored by the authorities of the European Union - for example, the censorship contained in the new French law on the so-called prohibiting the obstruction of abortion or concealing crimes committed by illegal immigrants in individual Member States. The authorities of the European Union must respect the voices calling for the law to be respected, no matter where they come from and where.

name: Емил Радев (PPE).
text: - Mr President, the effective implementation of European Union law is essential so that citizens and businesses can benefit from the policies we develop. The correct application of the law ensures that individuals and companies can exercise their rights and receive prompt and effective legal protection if those rights are violated. Failure to implement or implement the legislation properly will weaken citizens' confidence in the European Union. In 2015, mobility and transport, energy and the environment were the three policy areas with the highest number of potential irregularities. And the results in the reports show that the untimely and incorrect transposition of European directives continues to be a major problem in the application of European Union law. We must also mention the role that citizens and the European institutions play in ensuring that the Member States comply with European Union law. The large number of infringement proceedings in 2015 shows that ensuring the timely and correct application of European Union law in the Member States remains a serious challenge. In order to facilitate the application of European Union law by the Member States, Union law must be clear, comprehensible, consistent and precise, while taking into account the case law of the Court of Justice of the European Union, which emphasizes the need for predictability and predictability. EU regulations. I congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Chrysogonos, on his excellent report.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: - Mister President! Regulation is one side of the coin. The other side of the coin, but just as important, is of course application and control. The European Commission is the guardian of the Treaties and accordingly also responsible for both sides of this coin. The Commission's control over the application of EU law is therefore becoming more important every year. It is important that we ensure that our common acquis is preserved and that it is applied and implemented consistently. In addition to the important issues of application in the area of ​​asylum and migration, I would like to address the economic policy component in particular. There are now Member States that refuse or at least dilute the application of EU law in some areas, and they do so systematically. On the one hand, where it comes to implementation in national law. Here I would like to highlight Austria as a bad example with regard to environmental liability, which we will address in the next debate. On the other hand, however, also in the enforcement and enforcement of EU law - precisely where the functioning of the internal market depends on cross-border cooperation between authorities, where the states often have no interests of their own, some member states systematically show ignorance. I would like to mention a specific example here, namely Hungary. The Austrian Administrative Court recently found that, in the case of the posting of workers, judicial assistance is systematically denied in the case of Hungary, despite EU regulations that ensure effective criminal prosecution and the execution of sentences between the Member States. So it is a dispute related to the posting of workers. This is, of course, a particularly sensitive case, and that's why I try to ensure that both states really do EU law in these sensitive cases apply accordingly.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, Mr Andriukaitis, the European Commission is supposed to be the guardian of the Treaties. However, the question that lingers among the Greek people is who will ultimately protect us from the guards, and this is because the projects and the days of the European Commission as a member of the troika are one of the darkest points of the European Union. Instead of being the custodian of the Treaties, the Commission has been acting as the custodian of creditors' interests for seven years. As a member of the troika, together with the European Central Bank, it imposed memoranda, slashed salaries and pensions, reduced public spending, dismantled the health and insurance systems, filled Greece with armies of the unemployed and millions of the poor, turned Greece into a vast social cemetery. Thus, it violated the law of the European Union, the fundamental rights of the Charter of Human Rights and tore up every notion of democracy in Greece, as not only did not respect the result of the July 2015 referendum against the memoranda, but instead blackmailed its overthrow. So what application of law are we talking about?

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: - Mr President, in order for the European Union to achieve all its goals, it needs to work well. The European Union brings many benefits to businesses and citizens, but they do not come automatically. In order for people to enjoy the benefits of membership of the European Union and for the protection afforded to them by European law, states must implement and transpose European law and must guard it and want to comply with it. However, we are facing a transposition deficit, as this report on monitoring the application of the law in the European Union demonstrates once again. There are a number of negative phenomena. For example, different regulations, barriers, insufficient protection and uncertainty for companies and citizens of the European Union. There is also a need to discuss this deficit more, and to think more about how to combat infringements and proceedings before the European Commission and the Court of Justice in an effective way. It is also necessary to ensure the timely and correct application of European Union law, but we see that the established method is not active enough. I do not call on the Court of Justice to penalize anyone much more and to lean towards solutions that will have financial consequences. I call for more reflection on how to effectively explain the transposition debt in the Member States concerned. Over-indebted countries in particular, Greece or Italy have been mentioned here, and they are still unable to comply with these sanctions. That is why I want the European Commission to think about how to use its power and how it will continue to communicate more with the Member States.

text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, transparency and clarity are essential in the development and application of law by the European Union institutions and the Member States. We talked here about the smaller number of petitions, complaints, 3 450. For me it is a surprise that half, almost 50%, of these complaints come from three countries, which can be an example or will be an example for the Member States. newer, I'm talking about Germany, Italy and Spain. The number of human rights violations is much higher, but citizens, many of them, do not know their rights or are demobilized by the bureaucracy that exists in filing a petition. Petitions are an important source of direct information, not only on infringements and shortcomings in law enforcement in the European Union and in the Member States, but also on possible shortcomings in Union law. That is why we must take them into account. Personally, I receive a lot of petitions, not only from my country but also from other countries. I think, Commissioner, that you should not be upset - that is how I understood and maybe you will answer me. Parliament has a key role to play and must exercise political scrutiny over enforcement action, how the Commission resolves this issue and how it reports, transparently, annually to Parliament on this subject.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Mr President, like many others before it, this report again points out that the EU has been set up as a Union based on the rule of law and respect for human rights, a community of values in which the rights of minorities are respected and in which cultural and linguistic diversity is protected and enhanced. The report is right to point out that, besides monitoring violations and deficiencies in the application by Member States of existing EU legislation, the Commission is also bound to act in previously omitted legislative areas in order to give effect to Treaty provisions. This is especially true for cases where definite failures can be observed in the compliance with the founding values of our Union. For example, there is still no secondary EU legal framework to protect and guarantee the rights of national minorities living in the European Union, even though this is an area where the EU is very active in relation to third countries. As one academic pointed out, in the EU, minority protection is still an area destined for export and not for domestic consumption.  Such loopholes in EU legislation are very clearly visible, not only when Member States act against the spirit of the Treaties but also when citizens expressly point out issues in petitions or citizens’ initiatives. In this sense, it was definitely regrettable that the Commission only agreed to register the Minority SafePack European citizens’ initiative when forced by a judgment of the EU tribunal. To recall, the promoters asked the EU to adopt a set of legal acts aimed at improving the protection of persons belonging to national and linguistic minorities, and [noted] that strengthening cultural and linguistic diversity in the Union is something that is a founding value of our Union. The implementation of EU law is a  priority, but so is acting on such long-standing omissions with clear negative consequences on the lives of millions of EU citizens.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Mr President, the proper application of European Union law is important, especially from two points. It enables the European Union to function properly and provides legal certainty for citizens and institutions and, of course, for businesses, that they can rely on the law in force, that they can act in confidence in the law in force. Control of compliance with European Union law is entrusted to the Commission and also to the citizens. As far as the civic control is concerned, I think that we should be very interested in it and that we should be helping this very citizens' initiative. As one of those moments that we repeatedly call for, there is a demand for the establishment of one central portal for filing complaints, but also for information on initiated infringement or non-compliance proceedings. It is very important for me that there is a decrease in the number of initiated proceedings, which is undoubtedly due to the lower legislative activity in this election period, which I acknowledge. On the other hand, the violation is still extremely serious. I consider the violations of environmental rights to be particularly serious examples, and it is not just the new Member States. It is, for example, Austria. I do not want to draw a dividing line between the old and the new Member States, but it is important that, especially in the field of the environment, the rule of the European Union really falls on. As far as gold-plating is concerned, I would like to make one more important remark here. I think we should really emphasize the role of national parliaments as well. Finally, I would like to thank the rapporteur for presenting a very good report.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D).
text: - Mr President, congratulations on your name day. I congratulate the rapporteur of the report, Mr Chrysogon, on his report, which inevitably includes compromises, but I also particularly welcome the reference to the rights of European citizens, which are being violated by the economic crisis. The rule of law is in the best interests of European citizens. The implementation of the rule of law is primarily the responsibility of the European Commission and this is not a theoretical issue, it is a practical issue. Judgments of the courts of the European Union, of the Court of the European Union, concerning fundamental rights are violated and do not apply in Cyprus. And I conclude, Mr President: the European Union, under the Treaty of Lisbon, must be an area of ​​freedom, security and justice. This is the vision, this unites us.

name: António Marinho e Pinto (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, I congratulate Mr Chrysogonos on the meaning of this report, on the excellent work he has done and, above all, on the courage to include in it some aspects of reality that the political conveniences of circumstance could advise to omit. I refer to the negative influence that the austerity measures applied in some Member States have had on the administration of justice. I myself witnessed this in Portugal, because, as president of the Portuguese Bar Association, I wrote twice to the International Monetary Fund, the European Commission and the European Central Bank, warning of the catastrophic effects that a crazy policy of justice based on austerity was cause in the functioning of the judicial system. Commissioner, it is urgent and imperative to take measures to deepen European integration in the area of ​​justice. The Union's institutions will function much better and, above all, some judicial systems in Member States will be modernized, which are closer to the models of the Holy Office than to the models of justice in democratic states.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: - Mr President, happy birthday. I would also like to congratulate Mr Chrysogon on the thorough way in which he addressed some critical and sensitive issues in his report. One aspect that must concern us in the application of European Union law is the delay with which it is applied by some states, as well as its non-application by others, despite the fact that they know that they will have consequences. The reason for this development is the fact that the law, in many cases, does not meet the requirements of modern society and does not meet its needs. In addition, there is very little co-operation with national parliaments and the European Union often requires decisions to be made that are against the interests of certain states. A typical example is Greece in which, in an unacceptable way and in violation of the principle of solidarity, it has imposed the memoranda and has turned the country into a vast concentration camp of unhappy people.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, colleagues, thank you very much indeed for your comments, questions and suggestions. If I may, let me start with Ms Hautala’s question on administrative procedures because this is a very fundamental one.  The Commission is committed to guaranteeing that citizens, businesses and stakeholders can interact with an administration that is open, independent and efficient. For that purpose, the Commission, as well as other institutions and bodies, has a well-established set of horizontal rules which govern its administrative behaviour.  This includes, among others, a strong commitment made by laying down general provisions in the Code of Good Administrative Behaviour, which must guide administrative conduct in relations with citizens, as well as a range of provisions in legislation on staff and financial regulations, on data protection and access to documents, to name but a few. In addition, the Annex ‘Administrative procedures for the handling of relations with the complainant regarding the application of European Union law’ to the communication ‘EU law: Better results through better application’, on relations with a complainant in respect of infringements of Union law, specifically protects the complainant’s position in the informal phase of the infringement procedure.  These measures include: first, a 12-month time limit from the filing of the complaint, within which the Commission should, as a general rule, decide whether to initiate an infringement procedure or not; second, the possibility for the complainant to meet the representatives of the Commission in order to present his/her argument; and, third, the requirement to give prior notice should the Commission intend to close the case, thus allowing the complainant to raise new arguments within four weeks.  The Commission is, therefore, at this stage not convinced that the benefits of using a legislative instrument that would codify administrative law would outweigh the costs. New legislation would require the revision of a considerable volume of existing European Union legislation. Even when done with care and a sense of proportion, codification is likely to lead to problems of delimitation between the general and specific laws, not making legislation any clearer or litigation any easier for citizens and businesses affected. It would also remove the flexibility required to adapt to particular needs.  The second question concerning the role of Parliament in monitoring the implementation of EU law was raised by Ms Grapini. Without prejudice to the democratic control by Parliament, under Article 17 of the TEU it is the Commission which oversees the application of European Union law, under the control of the Court of Justice of the European Union.  The infringement procedure, under Articles 258 and 260 TEU, form part of a specific sui generis competence conferred directly on the Commission under the Treaties. Therefore, the infringement procedure has a specific bilateral nature. It is conducted solely between the Commission and the Member State concerned.  Some Members of Parliament raised questions about Greece and Cyprus, especially Mr Marias, Mr Mavrides, and others.  I would just say that the Greek and Cypriot Memorandums of Understanding were not part of European Union law because they led to intergovernmental financial support. The Greek and Cypriot Memorandums of Understanding were only formally agreed between the lenders and the beneficiary Member State.  The Court of Justice confirmed that, when adopting and implementing measures under such an intergovernmental adjustment programme, the national authorities of the concerned Member State do not implement European Union law.  Referring to some political statements about double standards and so on, as you know very well, the rule of law, the European Union Treaties, procedures and competences, are enshrined in a crystal-clear legal framework. Here it doesn’t matter whether it is a small country or a big country, we have the same possibility to start these procedures if the situation allows us to do it. The procedure to address infringements is the same for all countries, and the Commission takes all cases very seriously, whether it concerns cases in Hungary, Germany, or  any other country.  Mr President, honourable Members, the Commission very much shares your interest in the correct application of EU law, which is necessary for the benefit of European Union citizens, businesses and public administration. The Commission looks forward to continuing its work with Parliament on this very important topic.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος
text: Rapporteur. - Mr President, I, for my part, wish you well on your name day. I would like to thank all my colleagues, both the vast majority of speakers who have commented very positively on my report and those who have expressed critical views, because in a democratic dialogue criticism, when it comes to the substance of the issues, can sometimes give us the opportunity for fruitful reflection. The bottom line is that the European Union is now in a state of doubt about its future. Some time ago, a Member State for the first time decided to leave with the vote of its citizens. But the challenge is not limited to that Member State. It is clear that a large portion of European citizens feel that the Union's policies do not adequately serve the common welfare goal of its peoples, as proclaimed by its founding treaty. These concerns of the citizens must be taken seriously by the Union, and in my view the way to address them is to be more committed to primary European law, to the Treaties, and in particular to the Charter of Fundamental Rights, with emphasis, I would tell you. in social rights. The right to health, the right to education, the right to work, the right to social security, in general the rights to a dignified human life. For this to happen, more solidarity is needed, both between Member States and within societies, with redistribution from the rich to the poor and not the other way around, as is largely the case today.
