name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Laura Ferrara, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs, on the implementation of the Environmental Liability Directive (2016/2251 (INI)) (A8-0297 / 2017)

name: Laura Ferrara
text: rapporteur. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as a spokesperson for the 5 Star Movement in the European Parliament, I am particularly proud to be able to present this ambitious but realistic report on the implementation of the directive on environmental liability. In fact, there is a very close and deeply felt link between the fruit of this work and the reasons why I, together with millions of other Italian citizens, are working politically to change the things that we believe are not going well, both in Italy and Europe. One of these reasons, symbolically represented by one of the 5 stars of the Movement, is precisely the protection and respect of the environment in all its forms, as a unique and fundamental asset for life and also for future generations. I am therefore very pleased that this commitment has been shared by my colleagues from the other political groups, whom I thank for helping to make the proposal we are addressing to the European Commission even more ambitious and advanced. The first consideration that must be made in the matter of environmental liability is that the implementation of the directive, which took place in an uneven and superficial manner, did not achieve the desired results. More efforts are needed to make possible a standardization of the rules on environmental liability in the European Union and, in this sense, it is necessary to provide a unambiguous interpretation of the concept of significant significance of environmental damage and to introduce standard administrative procedures for notification of threats of environmental damage. Above all, we ask that the directive be updated as soon as possible, expanding the notion of environmental damage and its scope of application, in particular with reference to the criteria for determining the negative effects on protected species and habitats, the risks of damage to water and the soil. but also to human health and the air. This notion should be updated in order to make it sufficiently effective and coherent and to keep pace with the rapid evolution of pollutants produced by industrial activities. We are convinced that the costs of repairing the environmental damage borne by operators can be reduced through the use of mandatory financial instruments such as insurance or similar guarantees, which we ask for the introduction. It would also be appropriate to set up a European fund for the protection of the environment from damage caused by industrial activity, governed by the directive, to deal with the risks of insolvency and only in cases where the financial guarantee markets should fail. This fund would also be used in cases of environmental disasters caused by industrial factors when it is not possible to identify the operator responsible for the damage. On the other hand, it is necessary to act on the prevention front with information, awareness and responsibility actions based on the "polluter pays" principle. With this in mind, it is requested to evaluate the introduction of a civil liability regime for damage caused to human health and the environment. The proposal to establish a register for operators carrying out dangerous activities and a financial monitoring system to ensure that operators are solvent goes in the same direction. Particularly effective, then, would be the provision of tax relief or other forms of reward for companies that are successfully committed to the prevention of environmental damage. We also believe that citizens must play a non-secondary role in the system of environmental responsibility. Therefore it is necessary to provide them with adequate reporting tools, both to solicit the intervention of the competent authorities and by introducing collective compensation mechanisms for violations of EU environmental law. And again we ask for the adoption of a mandatory secondary liability regime that extend the liability to those who buy a company that causes the damage.All this, such as the proposal to set up specific independent authorities with management powers, we believe can benefit the protection of the environment and the health of citizens.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the Commission thanks Parliament for tabling this important initiative and appreciates the efforts undertaken to look into the implementation of the Environmental Liability Directive (ELD). The Environmental Liability Directive sets the EU framework for prevention and remediation of damage to biodiversity, to water and to land. It is based on the ‘polluter pays’ principle. Many findings and suggestions in the draft report and motion for a resolution are consistent with the Commission’s own report and evaluation of the Environmental Liability Directive in 2016. In the wake of that report, we are now working together with Member States and stakeholders to improve their implementation of the directive, including developing the knowledge base, the expertise and administrative capacity for applying the directive. The shortcomings of the Environmental Liability Directive need to be addressed: first, the unsatisfactory non—level playing field; second, the under-developed capacity; and third, the insufficient financial security level in many Member States. The Commission will work on these issues with the Member States and stakeholders in the context of the Multiannual Work Programme 2017-2020. The Commission’s view is that the directive’s potential still needs to be fully exploited by making more use of it and by applying it more consistently. Only after this should we consider legislative amendments. The systematic collection and analysis of data and information on environmental liability should lead to an ELD information system shared with all interested Member States. This would facilitate the future implementation of the directive. We will need to see how this initiative improves the implementation on the ground before considering extending the scope of the directive and before considering whether damage to air, or to health, should be covered.  We have made a clear commitment to perform a new REFIT evaluation of the directive in four to six years’ time. That will provide the needed evidence base for future action. I thank Parliament for supporting all efforts to improve the implementation of the Environmental Liability Directive, especially in the framework of the Multiannual Work Programme. Thank you for your excellent report.

name: Емил Радев
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, I would like to congratulate Mrs Ferrara on her report and thank her for her excellent cooperation during the negotiations. The Environmental Liability Directive entered into force in 2004 and its transposition in the Member States was completed in 2010. It has since been amended three times. The report reiterates its call for a change related to extending the scope and imposing liability for damage to human health and the environment, including air damage. The three previous amendments to the Directive have not yielded the necessary results. It is therefore particularly important to carry out the necessary studies and impact assessments in the event of a future extension of the scope. This will create an effective common framework for preventing and remedying environmental damage at a reasonable cost to society. It is important to use financial guarantee instruments and for Member States to take measures to accelerate the development of these instruments and markets, including financial mechanisms in the event of insolvency. This will ensure that damages are covered, even in the event of the insolvency of economic operators. However, I do not believe that the creation of a European Fund for the Protection of the Environment from Damage Caused by Industrial Activity will help to improve the functioning of the 'polluter pays' principle enshrined in the Directive. In order to better implement the Directive, the European Commission needs to adopt guidelines to help transpose it correctly into national law. Strengthening the training of professionals and lawyers in the field of environmental liability will also contribute to better protection of the rights of those affected by environmental damage. Only in this way will we be able to provide our citizens with a safe and stable disaster management system based on risk-sharing, enhanced responsibility and the 'polluter pays' principle.

name: Benedek Jávor
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. – Mr President, sorry for being late; I was at the trilogue. The Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI) participated, in accordance with Rule 54, in the discussion on the Environmental Liability Directive (ELD). The ELD is a key piece of legislation aiming to establish a framework of environmental liability based on the ‘polluter pays’ principle and to prevent and remedy environmental damage. As both the Commission’s report and the Committee on Legal Affairs highlighted, despite some improvements, the directive has shown incompleteness and thus limited effectiveness. Implementation still varies significantly from one Member State to another. We have a patchwork of liability systems, due also to the interplay with already—existing national laws, which in my opinion can undermine the common standards and expose some Member States or regions to a greater risk of environmental disaster and the financial consequences thereof. As is clear from the ENVI opinion, better implementation of the directive, including improving the information base and providing more training and assistance to the Member States – a key pillar of the Commission’s action plan and multiannual work programme – is needed, but is far from being sufficient. We should address the remaining challenges in a systematic manner and revise the directive in the near future, in the light of the Commission’s recent Regulatory Fitness and Performance (REFIT) exercise. A revision would allow us to extend the scope and applicability of the directive by making operators of all activities strictly liable for all environmental damage they cause, which means removing the limitation in Annex 3. In this context, the INI report rightly calls on the Commission to impose liability for damage to human health and the environment in the future and also calls for the removal of certain exemptions.  I also welcome very much the call for rethinking the financial security system, which is at the heart of the matter. This would entail high-level mandatory environmental liability insurance for operators, differentiated ceilings for activities with different risk factors and the creation of an EU—wide fund to bear the cost of relevant measures beyond the mandatory security in the event of large—scale disasters. I also stress that proper involvement of inspection bodies is key. In this context, the Commission should further develop inspection support capacity at EU level and help the Member States strengthen their national bodies.  Let me highlight one more message: we urgently need EU legislation on the minimum standards for implementing the Aarhus Convention ‘Access to Justice’ pillar.

name: Jytte Guteland
text: for the S&D group. - Mr President! I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Laura Ferrara, for her work in producing this report and for good cooperation. Ecosystems are the basis for life, health, prosperity and societal development. We are dependent on our environment and on our human actions, so we must protect the environment much more. The Environmental Liability Directive arose from the need for common rules at EU level to protect the environment. It was adopted as early as 2004 and the Member States had three years to transpose it into national law, but nevertheless it took until 2010 before it became a reality. This is incomprehensible. The Commission's report also provides a worrying picture of the actual application of the Directive. The directive has been implemented in an inconsistent manner, which has also led to inconsistent and incomplete registration of environmental damage. Therefore, in the report, we propose clearer guidance documents for operators, relevant authorities, environmental organizations and insurance companies. We must protect the environment. It is the foundation of life and health and brings joy both to us in our time and to future generations. It is important that we remedy significantly more environmental damage than those covered today. People with different experiences and backgrounds share the same air. We know that thousands of people around Europe are dying due to poor air quality. Therefore, we must have common rules at EU level also for environmental damage involving the air. I assume that the Commission will address this in the preparations for a forthcoming revision. Many studies also show that at the national level there has been no guidance or practice for when an injury should be considered a serious environmental injury. We therefore propose to the Commission to create public databases to enable businesses and citizens to become aware of the Environmental Liability Directive and its application. This would lead to better remediation and prevention of environmental damage. For our group, it has also been one priority, and I am glad that it is with us, that the Commission is developing the possibilities for collective redress for breaches of EU environmental law.It provides more opportunities for redress.If we are serious about achieving the EU's goals for sustainable development, then we must do much more.Therefore, it is high time that the European Commission revises this directive so that more damage to health and the environment is covered by the directive.This must happen soon, the polluter pays principle must be applied and this principle must always guide the application of the directive.In view of this, I wonder what the Commission is doing today and what the plan is for the forthcoming revision?

name: Ангел Джамбазки
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr President, first of all I would like to thank my colleague Ferrara for his efforts and work on this dossier. Protecting the environment is an investment in the future, and this is probably understood by everyone, and is a supreme manifestation of patriotism. Definitely, the 'polluter pays' principle must be encouraged, because it is the only fair principle on the basis of which environmental protection can be achieved. The purpose of the review of the implementation of the Environmental Liability Directive is ambitious and I welcome it. However, there are specific texts that call for broadening, changing definitions, harmonizing the significant threshold for the whole of the European Union, etc., which do not coincide with our political views of the Group of European Conservatives and Reformists. Although we support the initiative to strengthen the legal framework in order to better protect the natural environment, I would like to emphasize that this should not be in order to strengthen, tighten existing rules or regulations, but is a matter of better implementation. . The creation of excessive administrative burdens usually leads to negative effects, such as undermining the balance and the natural way in which the single market operates.

name: Anneli Jäätteenmäki
text: On behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, the idea of ​​the Environmental Liability Directive is simple: the polluter pays. The person who causes the environmental damage must pay for the damage caused by repairing the damage and restoring the environment. Unfortunately, the implementation of environmental responsibility varies greatly between Member States. The polluter does not always pay. Deficiencies in implementation undermine the well-being of areas prone to environmental damage and also the well-being of people. It is not uncommon for the outermost regions and the economically weakest regions to also have poor management of environmental damage. At worst, damage repair work can take a long time and in the worst case, damage and repairs are completely forgotten. If the polluter is not held liable or if the state, depending on its own legislation, is not obliged to finance remedial measures from its own purse, the highest price will be paid by people, soil, water bodies, animal species and the environment of the entire contaminated area. The report we are voting on today calls for clarification of the scope for interpretation of the definition of environmental liability. The particular weakness of the Directive is its loose definition of significant environmental damage. The Commission must address this as a matter of urgency. We also demand that the Commission re-evaluate the directive and thus impose requirements on environmental non-life insurance and financial security for the operator at risk. Finally, the Commission must seriously consider whether negligent measures to reduce air quality, such as the recent particulate matter scandal, should also be included in the scope of this directive. It is a matter that has the greatest impact on the environment and human health. It is time to act on this, and the Commission has not received any very clean papers either.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, the report on the directive on the prevention and remediation of environmental damage concerns us all. The purpose of this Directive was to establish a common framework for damage based on the principle that "the polluter pays". To date, however, the results have not been as desirable, as there is misunderstanding between states, and the scope for sharing responsibilities is limited. We must therefore formulate a modern and functional definition of environmental damage, based on the rapid evolution of pollutants due to industrial activities, including special cases, such as offshore activities. The environmental liability framework should also be extended to include restoring ecosystems to their original state after the cessation of harmful occupations. We must realize that protecting the environment and the health of citizens is our primary responsibility.

name: Heidi Hautala
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, the Environmental Liability Directive is a ground—breaking one and it is a vitally important tool to defend European nature and its citizens and future generations. However, it is a missed opportunity. The directive is under—used because it is toothless and its scope is too narrow and it contains loopholes.  Also, the directive is too limited in its strict liability regime as it can only be applied to a set type of environmental damage as listed in its annex. That annex (Annex 3) covers water, land and biodiversity damages only. In particular, it covers them only in the context of certain activities that are included on a restricted list.  Furthermore, it is simply irrational that the directive does not cover rapidly—evolving pollutants, damage to air, fauna and flora and landscape, human health and air quality. It is my inescapable conclusion that for this directive to become genuinely operational and effective, we need to revise and enlarge its scope. We should consider the option of requiring subsidiary state liability to be made mandatory. I have heard no justifications that would convince me that establishing clear parameters for accountability in this regard would not and could not be warranted. Responsibility and liability cannot be outsourced, especially because damage to the environment and human health affects citizens and society at large, and not just the individuals concerned. In this vein, I strongly support the proposal by the rapporteur to consider introducing legislation to assist operators and insurance companies to make use of insurance schemes in cases of environmental damage – also by way of examining the option of making financial security mandatory for operators affected by this directive. I am sympathetic to the hesitation in imposing such an obligation on operators, but not having a requirement of mandatory security in this regard is simply too dangerous.

name: Jane Collins
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, any operator that is responsible for damage to the environment must be held accountable for their actions. However, the determination of the accountability should be down to the Member State. I am pleased to see that the ELD does not prevent Member States from adopting stricter rules – but who are you to grant that permission? You mention the establishment of a secondary liability regime based upon the systems already adopted by several Member States; one of those being the UK. But why a secondary regime? This is typical of the EU implementing more and more unnecessary legislation. The report calls for the consideration of a European fund for the remedying of environmental damage. May I remind you the EU does not have its own money? The money that you waste comes from the Member States. So if you propose this fund who is going to pay for it? Because remember, one of your largest contributors will soon be leaving.

name: Gilles Lebreton
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr. President, the protection of the environment is a major issue of the 21st century. The salvation of mankind depends to a large extent on our ability to insure it. The European directive of April 21, 2004 therefore undertook to make a contribution to this noble ambition, by implementing environmental responsibility on the basis of the "polluter pays" principle. However, several studies have shown the failure of this directive. We must therefore thank Mrs Ferrara for taking the initiative to propose improving European law in an area where states cannot simply act separately. Some of these proposals are interesting, for example extending the scope of the directive to air damage. We know, in fact, how worrying air pollution has become. But other proposals go too far, such as creating a European compensation fund or even granting tax benefits to companies that engage in the prevention of environmental damage. I think it would be better to encourage each state to create a national compensation fund to compensate environmental damage in the event of the insolvency of polluters. As for fiscal policy, I believe it should be a matter for states. It would have been necessary to respect the sovereignty of States more to hope to convince the Council to modify the directive of 2004.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI).
text: - Mr President, the greatest risk to the environment does not usually come from the activities of ordinary citizens but from large companies. They build the big factories, they drill and extract, they carry thousands of tons of oil. As recent accidents have shown, just one such event is capable of causing incalculable disaster whose impact can affect even future generations. Who does not remember the nuclear accident at Chernobyl, Fukushima or the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico? So we have to put the companies, but also the governments, before their responsibilities. Companies should have both civil and criminal liability in the event of an ecological disaster. Governments licensing companies, if they have not enacted strict rules, should also have responsibilities. By "responsibilities" I mean criminal, in addition to the immunities and other methods by which corrupt political and state officials avoid persecution. We did not inherit the environment from our ancestors. It does not belong to us. We borrowed it and we have a responsibility to give it to our children better than we received it.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE).
text: - Mr President, first of all let me thank all my colleagues in the Committee on Legal Affairs who have been involved in drafting the final text of the report. I will be voting in favor of this report, not only because the Czech Republic is mentioned here in a positive context, but because it is an overall balanced text. Citizens expect rules from the European Union that ensure a high standard of environmental quality. However, this can be achieved without unnecessary bureaucracy and the creation of new institutions. That is why I am not in favor of the creation of a European fund, as proposed in the report. However, I feel that the original text of the 2004 directive needs to be modernized, making use of the experience gained from its implementation so far. In the next step, the European Commission should focus only on those changes that are based on unquestionable facts and whose impact on the quality of the environment will be quite clear. Only such regulation will make sense.

name: Tiemo Wölken (S&D).
text: - Mister President! The aim of the Environmental Liability Directive was to introduce strict liability based on the polluter pays principle to avoid and remediate environmental damage. We have to state that it hasn't worked so far. The directive was implemented far too late and then implemented only inconsistently and fragmentarily; often it is not used at all. Even the obligation to report environmental damage is not met. Surely it cannot be that 86% of all damage should come from just two out of 28 Member States. We therefore need an obligation to set up a central public database that all citizens can access and inform themselves about environmental damage. We have to put our citizens in a position to enforce their rights, and in this respect opening up to collective redress is urgently required. Furthermore, air pollution must urgently be included in the scope. Every year we have 467,000 deaths in the European Union from bad air alone. That is 467,000 too many deaths in the European Union. In addition, we need to make definitions, such as the severity of environmental damage, clearer. Some of the definitions are too restrictive and therefore need to be updated so that liability does not come to nothing. Finally, environmental damage repairs cost money. In order to be able to pay for this removal in any case, we need a binding environmental liability insurance for operators and also have to clarify the question of secondary liability. In an emergency, we need an EU fund that steps in when companies are insolvent. It must not be the case that environmental damage cannot be remedied due to a lack of liquidity on the part of the polluter, because then even the best law will not help.

name: Julie Girling (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I think we need to remind ourselves that this is an implementation report and that the principles behind it are not at question. This is not an opportunity for Members to out—green each other here in the Chamber; it is actually a consideration of how well this is working. I understand the temptation to try to extend the scope to air, water and many other areas; these are issues that we all work on day in and day out, but this would not be necessary if these core legislative acts – those for example on the ambient air quality directive –  contained clear access to justice provisions based on the Aarhus Convention that Member States currently pay only the slightest lip service to.  You cannot identify shortcomings with implementation and then make it more wide—ranging, less specific, more complex and harder to implement. It simply does not make sense. I would simply like to remind Members that the impact study attached to this report says: ‘Stakeholders’ comments during this study indicate that they are not likely to accept the creation of a fund or scheme for a wide range of reasons.....’, and so it goes on.  So why deliberately put that in there when, actually, there are other routes we could take that would be much more effective. Giving citizens access to justice to me is the simplest and easiest way of doing that.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, on December 17, 2003, the European Parliament took a big step forward in the protection of the environment by adopting this directive on environmental liability. Protecting nature and biodiversity while focusing on innovation, on the techniques of the future, is clearly in the DNA of our Parliament, it is clearly in the DNA of European liberals. It was also my friend and former Dutch liberal colleague, Toine Manders, who was the rapporteur at the time and the maneuver for the Parliament, to bring to the baptismal font this community system for the prevention and repair of damage environmental. Whether it is GMOs and the risk of involuntary contamination of conventional or organic crops, or the carbon market, created in 2005 to reduce greenhouse gases, the principle applies every time: the polluter pay. In its 2016 implementation report, the European Commission recognizes that, while the 2004 directive is effective in repairing environmental damage and encouraging prevention, it has not yet - to put it diplomatically - achieved everything. its potential. As Mrs Girling recalled, moreover, this concerns the question of observing the application of the directive, and as our rapporteur has said, there is sometimes a gap between theory and the practice. Mrs Ferrara, who did an excellent job - I want to thank her - spoke earlier about inconsistent and superficial application. I wrote down his words. This is true for damage to protected species and natural habitats. We know to what extent the “Habitat” and “Birds” directives can be bypassed by certain Member States. The same is also true of the damage that destroys water resources. Another category still covered by the directive: soil pollution, which can have serious consequences on human health. The still, there is room for improvement. Progress which - it is important to say this - can also involve prevention. A very recent example: we voted here two days ago not to renew glyphosate in this case. I will not reopen this debate and I will not come back to the carcinogenic nature of the substance, but to its impact on soils. Simply doing without it would therefore be the most responsible attitude, which is environmental prevention. In conclusion, I would say - as others have said here - that we can obviously strengthen environmental law but, for me, the urgency is rather to apply concretely and completely this principle of the polluter pays in European policies and also - this is our paragraph 29, it is important, and this is what Mrs Ferrara is proposing - to set up this European fund for the compensation of environmental damage, because the victims are counting on us.

name: Νικόλαος Χουντής (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, in the implementation and implementation of the directive we are discussing, there are serious omissions and intentions to serve interests, both in the field of prevention and in the field of rehabilitation. In Greece we recently had the sinking of a 45-year-old tanker, which transported 2.5 thousand tons of fuel oil in the Saronic Gulf, just outside Athens, and caused a huge ecological disaster, but also great damage to professionals and fishermen in the area. Otherwise, there are three points in the report that I think should be taken into account. Firstly, with regard to the establishment of the European Damage Compensation Fund, it should be extended to all damages in general. A way must be found even in the form of interest-free borrowing and, until the culprit is found, we must prevent the damage from the beginning. Second, to cover possible damage in the licensing phase. For example, the shipowner in this incident that I mentioned to you before Greece declared financial to repair the damage and pay compensation. Therefore, a way must be found, either with insurance coverage or with insurance options. Thirdly, in addition to the administration, the public and the citizens must be involved in the control and recording of all this. In other words, measures are needed to implement the Aarhus principle so that citizens can participate in all the processes that concern the environment, that is, their lives.

name: Mireille D’Ornano (EFDD).
text: - Mr President, I thank our colleague Laura Ferrara for her work on this report, the main issue of which, namely repairing the damage caused to the environment by human activity, is particularly close to my heart. It cannot be denied that the traditional accountability mechanisms provided for in national civil rights increasingly find it difficult to answer this question. This is due to both the nature and the scale of the issues. Thus, it seems natural that concerted international action mobilizing all States should be favored for reasons of efficiency. I fully support the aim of this report to extend the definition of environmental damage to air, ecosystems and landscapes. Indeed, the current definition of the directive of April 21, 2004 is too narrow, and many fields of activity dangerous for the environment are not included in its scope. The environment is our common heritage, and our only right over it is to preserve it, protect it and pass it on to our children.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE).
text: - Mr President, we value here the application of the Directive on environmental responsibility that was approved in 2004 and then transposed a few years later. The objective was, without a doubt, to be able to prevent and repair any environmental damage under the principle that "the polluter pays". It is key, logically, everything that is prevention and repair in order to have sustainable growth and to be able to make economies work and societies are healthy. In this sense, the Directive intended to work in three fields: halting the loss of biodiversity, both in relation to species and protected habitats; the quality and quantity of water - being able to somehow stop the deterioration -; and also soil protection. The rapporteur, Laura Ferrara, contemplates what deficits the application of this Directive has, and one that has been observed throughout the session is the different application by the Member States. In fact, there are many differences in the number of incidents of environmental damage that trigger the application of this Directive between some Member States and others. Therefore, a quick conclusion is that we need a harmonization in the application of this Directive. The Commission has said so. All Member States will have to be compared and studied with comparative data to see what is really happening and from here we will see how we can improve the legal text. Several things are proposed: to broaden the scope of the Directive, both with regard - after technological and medical research - to environmental damage that can harm human health - and therefore also address this issue - , as well as everything related to air pollution. Ultimately, it is about complying with the 2020 Strategy of having integrated, but also sustainable growth, and, therefore, supporting the Commission in this study, in this data collation, This is to see the exchanges to see how we can improve the application of this directive, which will undoubtedly make our economy work and that we have a healthy society.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! Reality shows us that there is still a lot to be done if this directive is to be properly implemented. However, it is also important to try to expand the scope of environmental liability. Why is air pollution not included in the scope? This is really an issue that affects all people, children, the future, and therefore air pollution should also be reflected in the scope. I would like to mention a few cases that haunted our media - bad cases that fill the newspapers at home: combustible waste stored in a residential area in Budapest, the marine pollution off Harku in Estonia, the pesticide pollution of the groundwater in Korneuburg in Austria and the fish deaths in the Mürz in Styria after the commissioning of a power plant. These are all cases that would have to be avoided if environmental liability was properly implemented. It's about avoidance, remediation and, ultimately, always about the question: Who pays for damage to the living space of all of us? The sad reality is that many Member States implement poorly and laxly, and then it is the general public who have to suffer the damage, who then have to pay for this damage, and it is not the polluters who are held responsible. So the point is to establish justice as to who will be asked to pay for the damage. But it is also about holding the major industrial polluters who damage our environment responsible. The “polluter pays” principle is the only logically fair thing that comes to mind. In this respect, I urge you, Commissioner, to continue to intervene where the Member States do not or only inadequately implement them, and of course, on the basis of this excellent report, to ours The rapporteur is aiming for you to revise the rules where they should be more ambitious.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, when approving the Environmental Liability Directive in 2004, we used alarming figures. According to the European Commission, three hundred thousand sites in Europe have been potentially or actually polluted by harmful substances this year, and the cost of repairing such damage would be estimated at hundreds of billions of euros. I do not think that we have significantly more positive data available today. At the same time, full implementation of the Environmental Liability Directive was achieved, after considerable ups and downs, only in 2010. Seven Member States still face the problem of compliance. On behalf of the Confederation of the European United Left / Nordic Green Left, I would like to thank the rapporteur for a correct report. We agree with its conclusions in the sense that this directive now needs to be revised. We therefore appeal to the Commission. It is necessary to amend the definitions, extend strict liability for environmental damage and apply the "polluter pays" principle more rigorously.

name: Sergio Gaetano Cofferati (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too thank the rapporteur for her excellent work. The directive we are talking about was an important step of our Europe, of the institutions, but made with the limits that have been repeatedly recalled in the discussion. The transposition was slow, often inconsistent, different from the contents and objectives of the directive, and the delays in transposition allowed the verification of its implementation, which was also penalized by a very substantial and completely counterproductive delay. For this reason it is very important to review that directive also in the light of the limitations that have been highlighted. The revision therefore falls to us, it must be done quickly and must, I believe, start from an element, which is what many of my colleagues have remembered: understanding the damage caused to human health and the environment, including those relating to air, which are instead excluded from the initial directive. I believe that to this we must add, because it is important, also the establishment of a civil liability regime for damage caused both to people and to the environment as a whole. To be able to do this effectively, it is also essential to have periodic environmental inspections carried out by the European Union with its institutions. It is also necessary to give the possibility to people who have been affected by environmental damage to have access to judicial recourse, which is necessary in a short time. The timeliness in compensating the damage is sometimes worth a lot for the quality and the certainty of life of the people who have been involved, as we have seen in recent years. Finally, we need an information campaign, maximum transparency in the application of the directive and maximum information in knowing what can happen to European citizens.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE).
text: - Mr President, congratulations to the rapporteur on the comprehensive report and proposals to improve the directive. The directive is indeed general, and several unclear terms in it make implementation even more difficult. One of these terms is, for example, the threshold of significance of damage to the environment for which there are no assessment criteria. The Directive is further applicable only to certain types of environmental damage and this makes it further limited. Another limitation is the fact that damages related to large-scale incidents are not properly defined, especially when it is not possible to determine the responsibility of the polluter. Damage from pollutants from industrial activities has not been adequately defined. I personally welcome the idea of ​​establishing a European Fund for the Elimination of Environmental Damage. It is also a good suggestion to extend the existing definition of damage to air, flora, fauna, landscape and, most importantly, human health. I support the revision of the directive and Mrs Ferrara's proposals.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the need for implementation of the environmental liability directive has long been felt. I come from a wonderful land, for centuries called "land of work", which today is sadly known as "land of fires", a land poisoned by the burial of toxic waste from companies all over Europe, and especially in Northern Italy, which decades have used the illegal disposal services offered by organized crime to eliminate, at low cost, the waste from their production activities. First of all, a reformulation of the definition of environmental damage is needed to extend its scope to fauna, flora, air and landscape as well, and to extend objective responsibilities to other dangerous activities currently not envisaged. Rules should be introduced to facilitate operators and insurance companies, in order to increase the spread of an insurance regime for cases of environmental damage. Finally, further elements capable of improving the framework of guarantees for environmental damage could be the provision of a more adequate financial control system and the establishment of a national and European register for operators carrying out dangerous activities.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, the debate shows that the legal framework of the European Union does not cover the damage caused to the environment, so of course we need to regulate the issues so that there is full responsibility for the companies that pollute and there is a possibility compensation to those who have been harmed. I take for example the recent damage that took place, the infection in the Saronic Gulf, where although we raised issues for the recovery of the injured, businessmen, fishermen and those who are involved in the area and have been damaged, the European Union itself has shown that nothing has been done . There is, of course, the International Compensation Fund, and we must establish that in the European Union as well. Finally, Mr Andriukaitis, with regard to the previous debate, more or less as a Commission you "washed your hands" and pretended to be Pontius Pilate, that you know nothing about crime, you know nothing about what happened in Greece with the memorandum. But it was the Commission that oversaw the implementation of the memorandum, Mr Andriukaitis. You imposed the orders of the lenders in Greece, so you have full responsibility as a Commission and what you said earlier in the debate I think has nothing to do with it. I, Mr Andriukaitis, answer you because I did not have the right to answer before. You can not "wash your hands" as a Commission and say "I do not know what happened in Greece." Who supervised the implementation of the memorandum? You as a Commission supervised it. So you have a huge responsibility.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: - Mr President, the Environmental Liability Directive, as a common framework for the prevention and remediation of environmental damage, must include all pollutants and elements due to human activities and interventions. In this sense, in addition to the already existing definitions of environmental damage in the previous directive, we need to extend the scope to include damage to air, fauna, flora, biodiversity and ecosystems. In addition, cooperation with international organizations, in particular the World Health Organization, will maximize the chances of achieving environmental goals. Based on the "polluter pays" principle, the violators, in addition to the severe sanctions and fines, undertake the actions of restoration of the environment and restoration of the ecosystems to their original state. Protecting the environment is not a field of political rivalry and is a matter for all of us, considering that the environment is directly linked to sustainability, sustainable development and quality of life.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I am, of course, of the same opinion that biodiversity, protecting soil diversity and protecting water from damage are very fundamental values that we should protect for future generations.The 'polluter pays' principle is undoubtedly correct, but fundamental questions arise as to who the polluter is.In this sense, I would also welcome an extension of the scope of the directive.I think that this issue has been raised here and it would be appropriate for the Commission to respond to it subsequently.I think that the Fund for Remediation, an instrument for preventing and at the same time compensating for the damage that will occur to the environment, is also a very good idea.Generally speaking, for the proper functioning of the European Union, particularly in the field of environmental protection, it is necessary to ensure compliance with this directive and to extend its scope so that citizens can rely on it and act in confidence in it.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur from the outset, because, on the one hand, she has identified very well what needs to be changed in the directive, it is a balanced proposal, yes, everyone, from the citizen to the national and European institutions, we must be concerned with the protection of the environment. Of course, I would like a greater emphasis on prevention, because the polluter pays, but we are interested in environmental protection, not the money that is collected from the polluter. However, I point out that, very often, there is a lack of infrastructure. Companies have no way and where to store waste, for example, and there are no technical and technological solutions in the Member States. That is why I believe that there is a need for careful legislation so as not to create a discrepancy between Member States and, in the end, unequal competition in the internal market. It is important to clarify and harmonize the application of the Directive and specify here that it is not a standard administrative procedure to notify the competent authorities of the occurrence of environmental damage. So I agree with the amendment of the directive.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: - President! The principle behind the Environmental Liability Directive is that the polluter pays. In practice, however, we believe that many people see another principle: the privatization of huge profits and the damage caused by pollution to society and the population. We have seen this, for example, during one of the biggest environmental disasters in the modern history of Europe, in Hungary it was the red mud disaster. I would like to congratulate my Hungarian fellow Member, Benedek Jávor, on the report and the opinion, who is well known for his commitment to the environment and is also a good expert. That is why I dare to ask him, knowing the specific case of the red mud disaster, to what extent did he find that the EU Environmental Liability Directive was applicable, and to what extent was this report influenced by the lessons learned from the red mud disaster? I have a strong suspicion that, for example, points 30 and 31 were indeed influenced and motivated by all the shortcomings we have seen in the context of EU law on liability issues related to the red mud disaster.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D).
text: - Mr President, indeed, the polluter pays principle must become the rule in the European Union and this in all areas. From this point of view, as co-chair of the parliamentary intergroup “Common goods and public services”, I can only welcome the extension of the draft directive to the issue of air, ecosystems and the landscape. . As Saint-Exupéry said, taking up an idea of ​​the American Indians, we do not inherit the land from our parents, we borrow it from our children. Everyone must keep this in mind during their personal behavior. There has been a lot of talk today about glyphosate in agriculture, and I would like to salute the courage of the European Parliament on this subject. But I would like to address another issue, that of mines and deposits, which present serious problems today. In my region, Limousin, uranium mines have seriously polluted the landscape and the soil and nothing has been done to repair them. I think we have to find a way to ensure that from the outset, when you open a mine, you pay for its restructuring.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, may I address some very important topics which were raised, especially speaking about the call to consider the possibility to extend the scope of the Environmental Liability Directive (ELD) and to impose liability for damage to human health, including damage to the air. Within the REFIT evaluation of the ELD carried out between 2013 and 2016, the scope of damage was also extensively considered. It was, in particular, subject to one of the studies in the preparation of the REFIT evaluation and Commission report. The evaluation concluded that damage to air is a rather uncommon category for a strict liability system as it by its nature mostly diffused damage – inter alia, damage which cannot be clearly attributed to individually—specified liable persons. Similarly, damage to human health would also require a fundamentally different approach to that of a restoration in kind which governs the ELD. For human health damage, traditionally civil liability systems for personal or bodily injury and loss of life exist in all Member States. This is normal traditional or conventional damage dealt with through civil liability and enforced by courts, in contrast to environmental damage, which is dealt with by public authorities. However, I agree that the Commission should look into this issue within the next REFIT evaluation of the ELD. Given the problems with air pollution, particulate matter and nitrogen dioxide, dieselgate. Also, the question needs to be considered of whether the ELD is the most appropriate basis to deal with such issues. I understand, of course, that several Member States take different views, speaking about possibilities to introduce mandatory financial security and a European fund for environmental damage caused by industrial activities. The question as to whether mandatory financial security should be established at EU level was the subject of the first and second Commission ELD report in 2010 and 2016 and the REFIT evaluation. Also, the Commission investigated in 2012 and 2013 the feasibility of a European industry risk—sharing facility or fund. There are several obstacles, including the ‘polluter pays’ principle and, of course, the different views of different stakeholders. The Commission has therefore made financial security a topic and working area in the Multiannual Work Programme 2017-2020. The Commission will launch a comprehensive investigation of the situation and challenges in the EU by looking also in the individual Member States, paying particular regard to the mentioned big issues of ELD concerning financial security and with a view to coming up with as many concrete interpretations and recommendations as soon as possible. Honourable Members, while there may be some differences in views on the immediate way to further implement and develop the Environmental Liability Directive to make it more effective and efficient, we agree in principle with most of the views and ideas in the report. But, at this point in time, rather than launching new or amended legislation, we should work on better implementation, notably through the joint ELD Multiannual Work Programme 2017-2020.  The Commission is already implementing this Work Programme, and recently brought together stakeholders and government experts at a workshop which led to a common understanding document with practical measures to help competent authorities, operators and other stakeholders to implement the ELD. All the results are available on the Commission’s Environmental Liability webpage.

name: Laura Ferrara
text: rapporteur. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank all the colleagues who have spoken, I thank my colleague Jávor for the excellent collaboration and I thank all the shadow rapporteurs who, with their proposals and their collaboration, have enriched the final text that we will go to today vote. I hope to find the same consensus in this plenary session that we already received in the vote in the Legal Affairs Committee but, from today's debate, it seems to me that it converges on some main points, namely the fact that this directive, in our opinion , must absolutely be improved in implementation in the individual Member States because, to date, the two objectives it set out to achieve, namely the prevention and repair of damage, have unfortunately remained unfulfilled in the vast majority of Member States. To do this, it is necessary for every single country of the European Union to equip itself with new instruments, such as those proposed in this report. I refer, in particular, to a mandatory register, in order to guarantee constant monitoring. Only in this way can environmental damage be prevented. When it comes to environmental damage, and when it comes to the protection of the health of citizens who, indirectly, are harmed when damage is done to the environment, it is important to prevent, because then the subsequent compensation, also in economic terms, unfortunately it will never be able to fully restore the injured health or to restore the violated environmental situation. And why is a European fund also important? Because within the European Union it is clear that there are situations of waste transport companies that belong to one member country and operate in another. This is why it is important that the fund be European, and not just national, because in this case collective protection can be created throughout the territory of the Union. To date, unfortunately, everything this is missing.There is also a lack of mandatory financial instruments that companies that carry out potentially dangerous activities must have, because the case occurs in which the companies, the companies in question, fail and therefore the "polluter pays" principle is harmed, becauseit becomes impossible to go back to the person directly responsible and, on his part, to restore the injured situation.I hope that the European Commission takes this report into account and that there can therefore be a real improvement both for the environment and for the health of citizens.

name: Presidente. –
text: I have the honor to announce that the Conference of Presidents of the political groups has just decided to award the 2017 Sakharov Prize for freedom of thought to the democratic opposition in Venezuela, to the National Assembly represented by its president Julio Borges and to all political prisoners. , as listed by the Venezuelan Criminal Forum and represented by Leopoldo López, Antonio Ledezma, Daniel Ceballos, Yon Goicoechea, Lorent Saleh, Alfredo Ramos and Andrea González. (applause) I have the honor of announcing this result on the day when, also thanks to pressure from the European Parliament, three human rights activists were released in Turkey. Since its inception in 1988, this award has been awarded to those who have made outstanding contributions to the struggle for human rights. It does not have a political color, instead it represents one of the most symbolic moments ... (laughter in the Chamber) Please respect the will of the majority of the Parliament, there is nothing to laugh about when it comes to millions of people and children who are starving! One may disagree with the majority, but the will of the majority in this Parliament must be respected in a democracy. There is nothing to laugh about when it comes to the defense of human rights! (applause) The Sakharov Prize represents one of the most symbolic moments of the function of our Parliament: to always be on the front line to defend and promote freedom, democracy and other human rights, inside and outside our borders. Today we have a duty to denounce, once again after five resolutions passed by the European Parliament in recent years, the serious situation in Venezuela. In this Latin American country, where many European citizens live and many Venezuelan citizens are of European origin, many are deprived of their fundamental rights, creating a spiral of institutional, economic and social crisis. The living conditions of the Venezuelan people have gone badly deteriorated. We are facing a real humanitarian emergency: there is a lack of medicines, medical assistance, food, drinking water and electricity. Hundreds of thousands of people are forced into exodus from the country. We cannot but raise our voice in defense of freedom, democracy, human rights. This is why we have decided to award the Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Thought to the democratic opposition, recalling our full support for the National Assembly of Venezuela, the democratically elected parliament, the only democratically elected parliament. (applause) We also want to call for a peaceful transition to democracy and for the creation of a humanitarian corridor to alleviate the suffering of the people. Today we are not only rewarding the democratic opposition: we want to express our will to be close and to pay homage to all the Venezuelan people, to those who have been unjustly imprisoned just for having expressed their opinion and to those who struggle every day to survive. a totalitarian regime, to families mourning the loss of loved ones during months of uninterrupted and peaceful protest for freedom. Today we support the struggle of a people for their freedom. But all the battles for rights are equally important. Whoever is oppressed, suffers injustice and is deprived of freedom and rights, anywhere in the world, will always be able to count on this Parliament. For this reason, the Conference of Presidents has decided to invite the other two candidates for the prize, Aura Lolita Chávez Ixcaquic and Dawit Isaak, who will unfortunately be represented by a family member, to the awards ceremony, which will be held on 3 December in Strasbourg, since he is still detained in Eritrea.

name: Birgit Sippel (S&D).
text: – Mr President, briefly, because a lot of myths – or you could also say a lot of lies – have been spread around by some industrial lobbyists. I would like to add some very short points on what we are deciding today.  The ePrivacy Regulation aims to put users back in control of their communication data and to make sure that confidentiality of communication in a digital environment becomes a reality for everyone. At the same time, the ePrivacy Regulation does not ban all forms of advertising. It only addresses the issues of surveillance-driven advertising and wants consumers given a choice about whether they want to be tracked or not for commercial purposes. Also – and I really cannot understand how this argument came into the debate – the mandate of the ePrivacy Regulation does not at all affect the powers of Member States to fight against illegal content online. Members today have a very clear choice: you can either disappoint the vast majority of citizens who want their confidentiality to be protected, or you can give in to the demands and lies of some industry lobbyists. Any further delay in this decision will only affect the strength of our position when it comes to negotiations with Council and Commission. Therefore, I urge everybody here to vote in favour of the mandate today.  (Applause)

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to underline the importance of cohesion policy. Cohesion policy is a most powerful instrument for reducing regional development disparities. In my country, Latvia, it gives more than 70% of investments in our economy. That is why we are very concerned about the future of cohesion policy after 2020. text: - Mr President, I voted against the report because there are points in it that I cannot agree with. name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the large question under Rule 130b by Piernicola Pedicini, Laura Agea, Rosa D'Amato, Tiziana Beghin, Marco Valli, Marco Zullo, Fabio Massimo Castaldo, Ignazio Corrao, Laura Ferrara, Eleonora Evi, Isabella Adinolfi, Joëlle Bergeron, on behalf of the EFDD Group, to the Commission on coordinated efforts at EU level to increase vaccination coverage (O-000074/2017 - 2017/2867 (RSP)) (B8-0603 / 2017).

name: Piernicola Pedicini
text: author. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we wanted to launch a debate on the issue of the mandatory nature of vaccines because recently, in Italy, a measure was introduced for the mandatory administration of six new vaccines, in addition to the four already mandatory vaccines, to a total of currently ten mandatory vaccinations. The data available on the Global Vaccine Action Plan portal show that this happened even though we were not faced with a real epidemic emergency that could have justified such a coercive measure. The Italian Ministry of Health justified this measure based on the measles incidence data of the first months of the year in Italy; these data were really worrying, also taking into account the fact that measles in Italy still remains endemic. However, many parents are worried about this drastic decision of the Italian Ministry of Health because they did not understand why, if there was an emergency for measles, a specific measure was not adopted to combat measles alone. They did not understand why the obligation was extended to ten compulsory vaccinations and, unfortunately, to aggravate the fears of the parents was the circumstance that such a delicate issue, concerning the health of our children, was brought to the center of the political debate and treated as if by two opposing supporters, with evident exploitation that we find very dangerous. This is why we wanted to talk about it here in the European Parliament, outside the national context and outside the moment of greater media attention, in order to be able to discuss it serenely in the interest of those concerned parents. Most citizens, and we with them, recognize the importance that vaccines have had in reducing, and in some cases eliminating (think smallpox), the incidence of serious infectious diseases. Yet those same citizens, and we with them, they want first of all that drugs, especially if administered to healthy people and children, to be effective and safe. Citizens want to know what real risks their children face when they agree to vaccinate them and the role of institutions should be to provide this information in a clear and transparent way. This is why we believe that politics should be concerned with making all control bodies, such as the European Medicines Agency and the national drug control agencies, independent and free from the pressures of the pharmaceutical industry (which aims for profit). who must be able to express their opinion exclusively on a scientific basis. We know that this is not always true and this does not help that relationship of trust towards institutions which is the basis for achieving the objectives of the national vaccination plans. Because, for those vaccines whose efficacy and safety have been tested, the question then arises of which strategy to adopt to achieve greater vaccination coverage and, if we look around, we note that most of the Member States, among the other those with greater economic and social development, have adopted an approach based on the conviction and accompaniment of families to vaccination, and not an approach based on mandatory nature. This is why we ask the Commission: from the information in your possession, can it be said that a coercive approach, based on mandatory vaccination, is more effective than an approach based on active recommendation and on the conscious accompaniment of families to vaccination? Second question: can the fact that the requirement to carry out a total of ten vaccines on children from zero to three years of age is unprecedented be considered a valid reason for invoking the precautionary principle? And finally: as part of the priority of industrial strengthening, contained in the letter of intents of President Juncker, Juncker himself has indicated a joint action plan on national vaccination policies.We ask ourselves how vaccination policies are a means to strengthen the internal market and industry, because instead we believe that health should be completely outside the logic of the market.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, vaccination is one of the most effective public health measures. Vaccination saves lives. Vaccination protects our societies, reduces illness and helps achieve long life expectancy rates. Vaccination not only leads to better public health outcomes, but it is also beneficial from a socio—economic point of view. Before vaccines existed, many children would die young or be crippled for life. Our generation has no memory of this. Thanks to vaccination, such diseases have almost – I stress almost – been eradicated. As President Juncker mentioned in the State of the Union speech, today in the EU children are still dying from diseases such as measles that can easily be prevented with vaccines. This is unacceptable.  So I want to thank Members for raising this major interpellation on a subject of great importance to all of us. Vaccination programmes have become increasingly fragile in the face of the low uptake of vaccines, vaccine hesitancy and vaccine shortages. Many people in Europe live and work in different Member States throughout their lives and have trouble in comparing vaccination calendars and vaccinating their children on time. Each country in Europe has its own vaccination schedule. They are the result of long traditions and therefore vary widely across the Union. Some countries opt for mandatory vaccination and it is their legal right to do so.  Honourable Members, I would like to address each of your questions. The first question is whether the obligation to carry out the 10 vaccinations for young children should be considered a reason to invoke the precautionary principle. First, 12 Member States currently have at least one mandatory vaccination in their national vaccination programmes and some have many more. Italy is one of seven Member States that prescribe between 10 and 14 mandatory vaccinations in their vaccination programmes. As such, the new Italian law does not constitute a so—called precedent in Europe.  The precautionary principle can be invoked when there is a suspected danger to human health and scientific knowledge does not permit an evaluation of the situation and of the risk. In the case of vaccination, we have scientific evidence—based knowledge on the benefits of vaccination. In this context, when considering vaccination programmes, it would not be appropriate only to take into account the small risk of potential adverse reactions to vaccines while ignoring the solid evidence—based benefits of vaccination. It would be misleading, in fact, at a time when people in Europe are dying from measles – a disease that should have been eliminated long ago because the European Union had obligations to eradicate measles by 2014, but we are not there. We need to strengthen our approach to vaccination. We need to encourage everyone to be vaccinated and protect the most vulnerable in society, leaving no one behind. Moving to your second question: can the Commission gather evidence on the effectiveness gap between mandatory and non—mandatory vaccination policies with regard to immunisation rates? The Commission can play a key role in facilitating the collection, analysis and dissemination of evidence—based research on the best ways to increase vaccine coverage. To this end, we will work closely with the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control and the Member States. Some studies show that, in the case of healthcare professionals, mandatory vaccination has indeed increased vaccination uptake. Our studies point to mandatory vaccinations not being decisive in determining childhood immunisation rates. As such, more data is needed to understand if, and how, changes in vaccination policies have influenced immunisation trends. Further research would help us to better appreciate the relationship between voluntary and mandatory vaccination programmes and vaccine coverage. I do not want to enter into a discussion on the benefits of voluntary versus mandatory programmes. They are all working towards the same goal of improving health. To do so, we need to analyse the implementation of the national programmes. Do we have appropriate surveillance in place? Is data available and used to inform future vaccination policies? How are targets met and what are the attitudes of health workers? That is very important. These are some of the issues we need to look at. Finally, your third question: how can the EU coordinate action to improve the effectiveness of vaccination policies and increase immunisation rates? As you will know from President Juncker’s letter of intent to the Parliament, the Commission intends to present an initiative to support Member States in strengthening cooperation on vaccination. Our aim is to help counter vaccine hesitancy and increase vaccination coverage, address shortages and prepare for emergencies, ensuring cooperation between Member States, involving stakeholders and ensuring a comprehensive research agenda on vaccination. We will work closely with a broad range of stakeholders from the health workforce, industry, academia, NGOs and patients’ organisations. In addition, next year I intend to launch a new joint action with Member States. This action builds on the results of the discussions with stakeholders that I held earlier this year. I hope it will pave the way towards a shared vision to improve vaccination coverage in the EU. This action, which will be co—financed by the health programme, will focus on the convergence of national policies on vaccination schedules and the evaluation of the effectiveness of vaccination policies. The aim is to increase intersectoral cooperation, promote cross—border interoperability and increase the consistency of communication on vaccination.  Together we are working, first, to increase trust and confidence in vaccines, which is very important, through vaccination programmes and health systems, and to enhance the effectiveness and sustainability of vaccination programmes and improve electronic vaccine registries. These efforts must be underpinned by effective communication and enhanced public engagement. We need to foster an understanding of the importance of vaccination as a key tool for preventing diseases. This issue is one that affects us all, irrespective of borders or nationality. It is one we must address collectively and strategically. I count on Members to support these efforts and help increase vaccination coverage in Europe.

name: Seán Kelly
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, the coordinated efforts to increase vaccination cover in Europe are of course welcome. However, I cannot accept some of the approaches which I have heard advocated. To suggest that legal requirements are not necessary for ensuring the highest possible immunisation rates is to disregard how crucial these immunisations are. We cannot take chances when it comes to the health and safety of our citizens and in particular, our children. We must take heed of the often life-saving health benefits of vaccinations for our children, as the Commissioner has just pointed out. Accurate and widespread information is essential to ensure citizens know how important vaccines are for their children. Safety is, of course, always a primary concern; now decisions directly affect minors. Unfortunately, it seems that public attention is often focused on vaccine safety and not on vaccine effectiveness. Modern medicine has allowed an extremely high safety record in vaccinations. Misplaced fears regarding the safety of vaccines have in the past caused a decrease in vaccination coverage. This of course caused outbreaks of diseases such as measles. For example, vaccination is not mandatory in Great Britain, and around 24 000 children a year in England are not immunised against measles, mumps and rubella. Part of the hesitation of parents to allow their children to receive the combined vaccination for these three infectious diseases was caused by a discredited study which claimed to show a link between vaccination and autism. This study has since been disproved. Vaccines are not only important to prevent disease in individuals; they are hugely important for communities at large and are proven to be effective in reducing child mortality. There is an obligation on governments to ensure that every citizen is given the opportunity to live a healthy life and therefore, vaccination should be mandatory across Europe.
