name: Andrea Cozzolino
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, do we or do we not all agree that vaccines are an effective tool for preventing epidemics and are the means to eradicate dangerous diseases? Do we or do we not agree that transmitting artificial messages, clearly bogus and without scientific validity is a way to create confusion and alarmism that lower immunization rates? Do we or do we not all agree that it is our political and moral duty to commit ourselves to ensuring above all that the weakest, the children, are not penalized by irrational behavior? It is good, it is really good, that the interpellation, rather than insisting on the alleged harmfulness of vaccines, focuses positively on the best mechanisms to spread the only immunization tool at our disposal against diseases and risks of epidemics. The introduction of the obligation, in the Italian case, is the testimony that too much has been played with uncertainties and with human fears, fomenting alarmism and spreading pseudo-scientific theories. Today's interpellation is a clear sign of a very positive change of pace, which allows us to finally bring the discussion back to a wider forum, going beyond national borders and involving the whole of Europe. This is the way forward: to open ourselves to discussions at all scientific levels. Only in this way can we avoid new accusations in the future, such as those recently made by the New York Times, which drew a dangerous parallel, in Italy, for those who actively campaigned on the anti-vaccine platform, repeating the false links between vaccination and autism. Or from President Juncker who, in his State of the Union address, recalled that it is unthinkable that children in the EU still die of avoidable diseases: in Romania and Italy, they should have access to vaccinations with no ifs and buts. We support the national measures of vaccination. Let's go to the facts, let's look at the data. In Italy in 2017, for example, in the case of measles as soon as the coverage fell below the critical threshold of 95%, the number of cases multiplied (4 689, the data of October 15), with 4 deaths. The possibility of seeing the risk factors for the weakest groups grow exponentially or of provoking the extension of the epidemic area to the rest of Europe is a real risk. What was the solution to this challenge? The principle was precisely that of adopting the precautionary principle, also invoked. He pushed the authorities on the best path to quickly raise immunization rates. On the other hand, in the world, things are not quite that different. For example, in the United States, Canada and Japan there is a ban on access to schools for those who are not vaccinated. Australia removes family allowances from those who do not vaccinate their children. Germany, which had no vaccination obligations, after 400 measles cases and the death of a 37-year-old woman, decided to fine parents who bring non-immunized children to the nursery with € 2,500. We cannot rely only on the rationality of the human being who, especially in moments of crisis and weakness, most of the time the result of pain, of a destiny deemed unjust, clings to all hopes, or worse remains prey to illusions. This is why I say: let's all go back to being a little more human, let's rediscover respect for years of studies and experiences, let's all put together to ban conjectures and theories without any foundation. Let's face the data in Italy. Every year 29 billion are spent on drugs, of which 318 million on vaccines. By way of example, we spend 1 billion for antibiotics, 300 million for antigastrics. Do we really think that the speculation of the pharmaceutical companies is wanted or can be concentrated on the smallest part of the entire expenditure? It would rather go investigated on how much families and people spend annually - we reflect on this - in the undergrowth of alternative examinations and consultations and on how much speculation there may be behind all this, especially the pain of so many families and so many parents.Commissioner, let's move on.I believe that we must go ahead quickly on a European road, perhaps with the single center for vaccine purchases, as announced, but also by harmonizing the systems of a centralized database to give more transparency to our information, as an integral part of that plan thatYou described it to give more confidence to citizens, to provide answers to needs and to restore hope to them.

name: Urszula Krupa
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Like most doctors, I appreciate the prophylactic importance and role of vaccination, but like some researchers, I have doubts about the safety of vaccination in newborns. The authors of the interpellation also ask about the application of the precautionary principle in the context of additional (already ten) compulsory vaccinations in Italy, the more so that, according to research, compulsory vaccination does not affect vaccination coverage, which is also important, before we know the real response to the intensive stimulation of the immature immune system and shaping nervous system. In Poland, an infant receives 26 doses of a cross-species antigen, including the vaccination against tuberculosis and hepatitis B carried out on the first day. It is worth knowing whether the child is able to respond properly to so many different stimuli and whether vaccination does not pose a threat to the development of the brain, for example due to the undeveloped blood-brain barrier, which is formed only in the sixth week of a child's life. Is it worth postponing the first vaccination at least beyond 2 months of age? After all, babies are protected by maternal antibodies in the early months of life, so vaccinations against certain microorganisms shortly after birth do not lead to permanent immunity. Babies do not have a developed immune system and do not reach maturity until about the age of three. Humoral immunity is associated with immunoglobulins that cross the placenta, mainly in the last 2 months of pregnancy, and the baby very slowly attains 50% of the adult immunity level only after 12 months. In my opinion, it would be advisable to study the authentic response from the organism of newborns, infants, and also children who, even though they are vaccinated, but who are sent to nursery and kindergarten very often suffer from various infections.

name: Ivan Jakovčić
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. - Madam President, although this debate came on the agenda primarily driven by the debates that are happening in Italy and everything that is happening in Italy, and a lot of, unfortunately, deaths, which we have heard about and which have unfortunately happened, I think It is positive that this debate came to our Parliament. There will always be those who are pro and contra for one side or the other, but I think we should use this debate for something else. Not only for the conflict, but for a constructive contribution to the exchange of experiences at the level of the European Union, the exchange of experiences between countries. In many ways many standards are similar, but not in all. So let’s say in this particular case where we have very different, I would even say traditions of vaccinating newborns or children. So Croatia has some traditions of its own, some situations of its own. I think that the role of the Commission, and here I want to encourage the Commission and the Commissioner to really make a very, very well-founded study and propose, in a way, what could be a guideline in the future because the quality of life and quality of life of newborns and all young people it increases day by day. And I think that these experiences that exist in the European Union are very smart and necessary to exchange.

name: Joëlle Mélin
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, if there is one area where Europe, in our opinion, could be effective, it would obviously be that of public health, since borders have nothing to do with the spread of microbes or viruses and that, there, in fact, a common position could make things easier in terms of public health for each State. Let us recall one thing: each Member State is free to adopt its public health policy and, today, see the appearance of a great debate in Italy, but also in France - since these days we see the appearance in French law of an obligation to carry out eleven compulsory vaccines from January 1 - means that, precisely, abrupt changes are taking place in the way of approaching vaccination. Many scientific questions are emerging, but also questions from parents who wonder, when France, at least, has experienced a shortage of drugs for ten years. Again, for market reasons and for the patents of certain monopoly laboratories, these shortages have meant that vaccination coverage has not been as good. The question arises as to why, when fifteen countries do not practice compulsory vaccination and twelve others impose only one or more vaccines, we have not had more epidemics than that. Why would it suddenly be necessary to have so many vaccines? I think my colleague Piernicola Pedicini must think exactly the same thing. Why all this? Why so brutally and what are the possible interests of the laboratories? All the more so since in France, we have nevertheless experienced two false epidemics - I do mean "false epidemics" - which gave rise to a reluctance going beyond even the criminalization of certain vaccines in the context of serious degenerative pathologies. So, I believe that our institution and the Commission must look and allow studies a priori and not a posteriori, not to impose anything in advance that is not of a scientific character, an independent character, unless we had to think - forgive me for worrying everyone - that someone ina country somewhere has information on bacteriological terrorism.As things stand, a moratorium on vaccine studies, in order to be able to determine to what extent and at what rate vaccination should be practiced, basically, in our various European countries would, in my opinion, be much wiser than'impose by saying: "Vaccinations are good no matter what."I think more hindsight would be necessary.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE).
text: - Madam President. It surprises me that, in the European Parliament, we are dealing with the Italian Government's decision to increase the number of compulsory vaccinations. All the more so as the initiators of this debate also acknowledge that only Member States can decide on a vaccination calendar for citizens. In addition, the precautionary principle to which they refer applies to Union policies. In matters falling within their exclusive competence, it is up to the Member States to decide whether and what principle to apply. We live in a time when a large group of people are questioning either vaccination itself as an effective method of combating serious diseases or the effectiveness of the legal obligation to vaccinate. The authors of the question for the Commission we are discussing here belong to the second group. They may not realize that this opens up space for charlatans, who can convince a large number of parents without medical education in a short time about their unscientific theories. The fact that they are successful is confirmed by the declining number of vaccinated children, and not just newborns. In addition, the material referred to by the authors is not a scientific study, but only a communication material that combines vaccination statistics with information on current legislation. It is not a study, as they claim, and it does not meet the criteria of serious scientific research. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, let us speak rather about the cross-border dimension of the risks associated with insufficient vaccination and the need for Europe-wide guarantees of non-proliferation in relation to free movement and migration. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162 (8))

name: Piernicola Pedicini (EFDD)
text: question "blue card".- I would like to ask my colleague if she is aware of the fact that vaccination lies in a field which concerns health and not health.Health is about people, about maintaining the health of people who are already healthy.We are not talking about sick people, so this is a competence that does not belong to the Member States but it is also a competence of the European Parliament and the European institutions.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: answer the question posed by raising a blue card.- Thank you very much for the question.We could argue about this, but vaccination directly affects disease prevention and therefore prevention, which is part of Member States' healthcare.So, I agree that these issues may overlap, but I think that in the context we are talking about, it is the competence of the Member State.Well thank you.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, there is no doubt in my mind that vaccines protect the population, especially today, where there are no borders within the European Union. However, Member States must retain sovereignty over their vaccination calendars and over the health of their citizens. The reason for this conversation is Italy, where mandatory vaccination of newborns was recently introduced, in this case 6 vaccines in addition to the four that were mandatory, become a total of 10 mandatory vaccines. The legitimate goal of achieving the highest levels of vaccination is understandable, but it can be achieved in two ways, either through stricter policies or through what is called a combination of referral obligation policies. A 2016 survey shows that countries where vaccination is mandatory have not achieved much better coverage than comparable countries where there is no legal obligation. There are therefore two questions: can the Commission gather evidence on the effectiveness gap between mandatory and optional vaccination policies in terms of levels, and how can the Union coordinate actions to improve the effectiveness of vaccination policy and increase immunization rates?

name: Jozo Radoš (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, even before this parliamentary question, there was a topic of debate about whether there is excessive or harmful vaccination. In essence, it is a broader question, whether there is generally an excessive or excessive use of drugs in the interest of the pharmaceutical industry, and it is equally very, very present in the public. I am convinced that vaccination is useful and I support the Commissioner's allegations, but I still think that, because of the questions that exist in public, it is good that colleagues have asked this question, especially the Commission to offer evidence and information on whether there is a difference between vaccination and compulsory and non-compulsory vaccination and whether there is a possibility to vaccinate unnecessarily or, indirectly, whether there is any interest of the pharmaceutical industry, which is not in the interest of the health of citizens. I also support the call for the Commission to work on standardizing, introducing the same rules or similar rules, or coordinating vaccination efforts in the European Union. And I am glad, in the end, that the Commissioner ended his presentation with the view that the European Commission is making efforts to increase vaccination coverage in the European Union.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, thank you very much indeed. Honorable Members, I am very happy to have listened to you, but if I may I will just say a few words in my mother tongue, Lithuanian, because as a medical doctor I would like to focus the attention of my colleagues, Members of the European Parliament, who have just mentioned some very important issues. Ms Krupa raised questions about newborn vaccinations and the number of vaccines. I have no doubt that Italy has a huge scientific force, a pediatric, immunologist, clinician, laboratory force, an excellent scientific base, and it is understandable that their steps to address these issues are justified. And very rightly, you are asking questions that should be discussed among professionals. For me as a cardiac surgeon, the benefits of mandatory vaccination are well understood. I had to vaccinate myself against hepatitis, other viral diseases. Why? Because during an intervention I can injure my hands and at the same time infect the patient, there are many professions where vaccination is mandatory. Whether or not there are any other criteria for studying autism is anything else when we know the scientifically based arguments that guide ourselves. I vaccinate myself against the flu every year in public and I invite you all to do the same. Is there a debate here about the pharmaceutical industry, or is it a debate about the ability of our own professionals in particular to show how important it is to prevent those infectious diseases that are controlled. Ms Mélin raised questions about the link between particularly dangerous infections, bacteria and the use of bacterial weapons in terrorism. And here it is especially important to emphasize that in the sense of prevention, new research, new searches are unspeakably needed. And it is a global agreement to have global regulatory rules that would allow us to mobilize resources for a preventive response if new infections are developed or a bacterial weapon is used. After all, there is the issue of health security here pat. Thank you very much for raising the issue of studies. Yes, those studies are needed and we will do it. And Mr Jakovčić mentioned the case of Croatia. Yes, in fact, you know that there are twelve countries where vaccination is mandatory, there are professions where vaccination is necessary, because otherwise, as I said, those professions can cause a lot of trouble in the spread of infectious diseases. I’ll make a little joke. We all know that when we drive a car, a technical inspection of the car every couple of years is mandatory, and while we have our own complex biological system, we can take care of it on an optional basis. Strange, let’s try to discuss. Let's cancel the mandatory maintenance of cars. When we talk about things infinitely serious, we suddenly start using a strange argument from a multinational company, but those arguments from an outdated arsenal should probably go deeper into numbers, problems, after all, Mr Cozzolino rightly said that we can't play games when we talk about people’s lives, but all the more so when we talk about children’s lives. I can’t believe we fail to control, protect children and control the measles outbreak. Donate, but it is completely unacceptable that we can close our eyes and say, you know something happened, well death, well what will you do, let’s keep trying to say, let’s not take action. I would like to stress once more that right now in Europe children are still dying from vaccine — preventable diseases that should have been eradicated in Europe a long time ago. We are all responsible. We all need to do more to stop this. I want to thank you for this inspiring discussion. I believe the time has come to engage with Member States with a view to increasing the acceptance and uptake of vaccines across the EU. In this context, I sense that there is a common ground to counter vaccine hesitancy - I see that we are all like — minded - to strengthen evidence, transparency and sustainability of national vaccination programs and to increase the effectiveness of EU vaccine research and development. Today's discussions show that there is a broad agreement on the added value of EU-level cooperation on vaccines. Together we must maximize our limited resources and work towards more convergent national vaccination policies. We need convergence in this situation. To this end, as I said earlier, the Commission is shaping a new initiative to support Member States by leveraging intersectoral cooperation, promoting cross-border interoperability and increasing consistency of communication. I am confident that this worldview will, in the long run, lead to better vaccination coverage across Europe and stop the tragic deaths of unvaccinated people in this context, especially children. I wish to thank you again, honorable Members, for your support. You play an important role in these discussions and I welcome your engagement. Let me assure you that the Commission and myself personally are fully committed to improving vaccination in Europe.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Thank you, Commissioner!We have seen a Commissioner who is wholeheartedly with what he says;it's nice to feel that too.Thank-you!The debate is closed.
